description:
CyberSpace Crossword is a freeware three dimensional crossword puzzle.

The player starts at a point in cyberspace some distance above the puzzle and navigates to it using three slider controls that adjust the player viewpoint in each of the three dimensions. The sliders to the left and to the bottom allow the player to look up, down, left and right; the slider to the right allows the player to move forward or backward along the direction the camera is pointing.

Upon nearing the puzzle the game begins and the player is offered the first clues. Cell 1 is preselected for the player to enter a letter. None of the cells are numbered, however when selected a cell changes colour and any associated clues are displayed in a window in the lower right corner of the game area. Answers are entered letter by letter and to do this the player must select each cell individually, enter a letter, then select the next cell, enter the next letter and so on.

The game has no help function and the player cannot progress to the second puzzle until the first has been correctly completed. The game is controlled with the mouse and the letters are entered via the keyboard.

The game is also called CyberSpace Cruiser throughout the documentation, and it contains an offer to purchase "virtual real estate in cyberspace": by paying 40 dollars, a player could claim part of the game's virtual space for himself, which would then be marked with his name in all future releases of CyberSpace Cruiser. The player could then store up to 32 kilobytes of data in the owned part of cyberspace (upon logging in with a username and password), effectively functioning as an elaborate form of clipboard. According to the documentation, the program also contains network support: when installed on a network, multiple users can log in from their computers, see the other users moving around in cyberspace, and converse with them.

sample_screenshots.caption: This screen shot shows letters as they appear in the crossword.
This is a better shot of the crossword. The cell selected is coloured red. It is not the start of a word so no clue is displayed.
You can change the color of the window
This part of the cyberspace is assigned to "Gregor". (Note the window title. It initially says "Cruiser", but approaching a crossword and then exiting changes it to the misspelled "Crusier".)
A tall white tower. It doesn't seem to do anything though.

title: CyberSpace Crossword

description:
Mazemaker is a shareware game which generates mazes through which the player must navigate. The mazes vary in complexity from the "Maze of the Day" to the "Maze of the Year" and while single screen mazes can be generated, most mazes are three dimensional.

Three dimensional mazes are spread across a number of floors. The player starts in one room and must navigate the maze to reach a specific room which the game will identify. The game is mouse controlled and the player navigates the maze by moving around their current room and selecting an arrow. The arrow will take the player up or down to a room on another floor. To help the player the game keeps track of their progress and shows where they have been. The mazes the game can generate are;* Single Floor mazes

  • Maze of the Day (easy) – restricted to 2, 3, or 4 floors these mazes change daily
  • Maze of the Day – these span 4-6 floors and a new maze is presented each day.
  • Maze of the Week – these span 7-9 floors and change every Sunday. These mazes are only available to players who have completed the "Maze of the Day"
  • Maze of the Month - these cover 8 – 10 floors and are only available to players who have completed "Maze of the Week".
  • "Maze of the Year" with ten large floors and restricted to players who have completed "Maze of the Month".

Partially completed mazes can be saved to be continued later and daily mazes can be named and saved to be played at any time.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the first screen of the maze. It shows the start and the end points.
Moving to the sole arrow in the first room.
The arrow takes me down to the first floor some distance from the starting room. There's only one way out of this room besides the arrow that brought me here
Been playing a while now. The trail showing paths taken is immensely useful as its easy to get lost and forget which paths have been taken

title: Mazemaker

description:
The Greens is a shareware arcade style crazy-golf game for 1–4 players.

The game consists of a single screen with all the information presented in a series of windows. The main window in the upper left shows the position of the ball and the topography of the current hole. The player plays the game using a mouse to manipulate the three controls below the main window.

The first control is a pair of arrows, one pointing up and one pointing down. This controls the strength of the putt. The second control is a white circle in a grey square. The white circle represents the ball and, using the mouse, the player positions a green dot which marks the direction from which the club will strike the ball. With the force and direction of the shot determined the player uses the third control to initiate the shot. An animation in the main window shows the track of the ball.

Each player has a total of eight strokes with which to complete the hole after which control passes to the next player. Should the ball go into a bunker the ball is replaced at the start point.

The object of the game is to complete the course in as few shots as possible.

Apart from the entry of the players names the game is entirely mouse controlled. It has an in-game help function, and a midi sound track and sound effects (both of which can be disabled) as well as a high score table.

The shareware version of the game has five holes. The full version has 18 holes and uses 256 colours.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hole 5 is the most complex yet. The hole is in the bottom right and the player must negotiate the complex water hazards and bridges to reach it
The first hole. Moby 1 will get to play up to 8 strokes to pot the ball before Moby 2 gets their turn. The orange bunkers are lava pits, the grey areas at the sides are bridges.
When a ball goes into a bunker the game plays a short animation showing its demise. Play resumes with a new ball on the strat point.
This is hole 2. The power meter is high for a long shot to try and get around the top corner.
Before the game starts the players must enter their names. Here 'Moby 1' is playing 'Moby 2' in a two player grudge match. The game supports up to four players

title: The Greens

description:
5-Game Super Pak is a compilation of games originally published by Masque Publishing, Inc.. It is part of Softkey's Platinum CD-ROM series and includes:

  • Masque ChessNet 3
  • Masque Solitaire Antics
  • Masque Video Poker
  • Masque Caribbean Stud Poker
  • Masque Blackjack
title: 5-Game Super Pak

description:
Masque ChessNet 3 is version 3 of Masque's chess program.

This version of ChessNet has options that allow the player to compete with other players via modem, null modem, BBS terminal Emulator, PC Pursuit Dial up, Network or Internet connections. Alternatively the player can play against the computer and in such matches can choose any of six levels of difficulty. It has a help function, based on the US Chess Federation rules, which explains the game and a feature that allows players to listen to their own CD's while playing.

The game comes loaded with 20 games from the 1993 World Chess Championship.

The game can be played entirely by the mouse, dragging and dropping pieces. However the keyboard is needed when entering players' names and when typing messages to other players. There are also keyboard shortcuts to some of the game's menu options such as save, load, hints e.t.c.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game has a help function, based on the US Chess Federation rules, which explains the game
This is the basic game screen. Menu items across the top contain all the game's control options. Here a drop down box shows the customisation options
This drop down box shows the multiplicity of network connections supported
Here one of the games from the 1993 WCC tournament has been loaded. This illustrates the way the game displays each player's moves and also the way captured pieces can be displayed
This drop down box is typical of the number of options available in defining a connection to an on-line game

title: ChessNet 3

alternate_titles.title: Casino Video Poker: Las Vegas Jacks or Better

description:
Masque Video Poker is a single player video poker simulation.

The game starts with the player either choosing an existing identity or creating a new one. The game can be played entirely via the keyboard or entirely via the mouse, or a combination of the two. There is no save game function allowing the results of one session to be carried forward to the next.

In a typical game the player starts with 40 credits and can bet 1,2,3,4 or 5 credits bet game. The game screen shows the winning hands and the payouts for each.

Once the bet is made the player clicks on the 'Deal' button and five cards are dealt. If a winning hand is dealt the game screen automatically highlights the appropriate line. The player may hold or any of their cards before selecting the 'deal' button for the final time. Any cards not held will be replaced by this re-deal. Again the game automatically highlights the winning line. If the player has won their winnings are automatically added to their current total.

The lowest hand the game pays out on is a high card pair, that's a pair of Jacks, Queens, Kings or Aces. Single pairs of other numbers do not win.

The game has in-game music and also allows the player to listed to their own CD while playing.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here a maximum bet of 5 credits has been made. Players make this bet by selecting the 5 credit or  Max Bet buttons. Alternatively this and smaller bets are made by clicking on the 1 credit repeatedly.
The ten of hearts was held and the remaining cards were redealt. A pair of jacks appeared so the original stake was recovered. The game will pause at this screen until another bet is made.
The game has a simple but effective in-game help function. This is one such screen detailing the keyboard controls
This is the start of a typical game. At this point no bets have been made and no cards have been dealt.
Here the first deal provided two pairs. Since the player must redeal its important to make sure the winning cards are held before pressing the Deal button a second time

title: Masque Video Poker

description:
Masque Blackjack is a blackjack game for 1 - 4 players in which the player can choose to play by themselves, against friends or against computer opponents. The game may be played entirely via the keyboard, entirely via the mouse or by a combination of the two.

All players start the game with $1000 represented by stacks of chips. Playing with the mouse bets are made by either clicking on the players stack of chips or, this action transfers the chips onto the players area of the table, or by dragging and dropping the chips onto the table.

When all players have made their bets the cards are dealt. Players have the usual options to Stand, Hit / Draw, Spilt, Double-Down and, where appropriate, take out insurance. Players make their selections. Blackjack is paid immediately, those players who exceed a card count of 21 are eliminated. When all players have made their selections the dealer reveals their cards and plays.

The game has an in-game help function. The mouse can be used to make hand gestures to the dealer as in a real casino game. Other features include playing the players CDs during the game, automatically counting the cards, optionally showing the credit balance of all players, and playing to a variety of different blackjack rules.

The game has no save facility so credits accumulated during one session are not retained for the next.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here the optional player's credit window has been enabled
This screen shot shows the different types of game that can be selected
This screen shot shows the game customisation options
The winnings are not added to the players stack of chips. They are left on the table and must be removed, unless the player wants to play for the increased stake
The cards have been dealt. The card counting option has been enabled and the player's hand is shown as totalling 11. The player has right clicked to show the available options.

title: Masque Blackjack

description:
Masque Caribbean Stud Poker is an officially licensed simulation of a casino card game for 1 - 4 players where either the computer or real people can take the role of players 2,3 & 4.

The game starts with each player placing a bet or "Ante" in the treasure chest lid area of the table. The cards are then dealt, all the player(s) cards are dealt face down but the top card of the dealers hand is placed face up. Each player in turn decides whether their hand will beat the dealers. If the player thinks there's a chance of beating the dealer they choose to bet on their hand which causes chips to the value of the original bet to be transferred from their stack to the table. If the player does not think they can beat the dealer then they fold and lose their original bet. The dealer then reveals their cards and players who have beaten the dealer are paid.

A feature of this version of poker is that the dealer must have an Ace and a King or better in their hand in order to qualify, if they do not have this minimum requirement in their hand then the dealer loses and anyone still in the game, regardless of what is in their hand, will win.

Winnings are based the strength of a players hand with two pairs paying out double the bet and four of a kind paying twenty times the bet. In addition there is a progressive bonus payout for hands that contain a flush or better.

The game allows the player to change various settings such as the speed of the deal, the minimum & maximum bet and to set automatic reminders for the progressive bet and other gaming situations. It also includes a CD player so that the player can listen to their own music during the game.

The game can be played entirely with the mouse, bets being made by dragging & dropping chips onto the table or by clicking on the stack. Alternatively the game can be played entirely via the keyboard or by a combination of the two.

There are no save game feature or network play features in this game.

sample_screenshots.caption: This screenshot shows the CD player which, if selected, stays on screen while the game continues. The player winning window must be removed before play can continue.
A screen shot showing the game's help function
In this hand the player with a pair of 6's loses because the dealer had a pair of Jacks. Player 1, however, wins again.
Players can be added at any time during a game. Here player 'Moby' was playing against three computer opponents and new player 'Moby 2' is being added.
The game in progress. The colour of the felt can be changed but the central play area is always black

title: Caribbean Stud Poker

description:
Dino Slot is a single player slot machine game based on a cave man / Flintstones theme.

The machine has been made to have as if it were hewn from rock, all the symbols on the reels are dinosaurs, and the slot machine handle is a branch of wood.

The slot machine pays out on twelve different combinations but these can be changed via the supplied Payoff Editor and the frequency of wins can be changed via the supplied Wheel Editor.

The player starts with seventy five credits and can play up to five credits per spin.

sample_screenshots.caption: The player pays in, and wins, rocks instead of coins

title: Dino Slot

description:
WinBlocker is a shareware falling block puzzle game.

The game is played via the keyboard or joystick and has a different block set to most other falling block puzzles. The player controls a brick firing cannon. The falling shapes must be formed into solid rectangles by the addition of these bricks.

This game is not about shooting blocks and blowing things up it's about strategically adding bricks to the shapes as they fall to form larger, rectangular shapes and thus generate more points. For example overlapping blocks can, if completed in the right order, be cleared as a single unit.

Once a block has been completed it disappears and the player's score increases. If any block hits the ground it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: It does not look as though this game will be completed successfully
The game runs in a small window. Here at the start of the game the first combination of shapes is falling.
This time the shapes are a little easier. Another brick in this slot and the shape will be complete

title: Winblocker

description:
Der Baulöwe is a managerial simulation in which the player takes control over a construction company. The obvious goal is to earn money and in order to achieve this, the company has to take contracts through call for bids. It is both important to have a good bid (high enough to be profitable and low enough to get the job) and a high workload distribution which binds all resources of the company, i.e. staff and equipment. Expansion eventually leads into processing multiple contracts at once and entering the field of land speculation.

Before starting a game, the player can choose the country in which the company is registered. This influences the running costs and the employees available for hire. People with low qualification are cheap but also influence the construction results negatively. The interface is completely based on menus in which the player analyzes the numbers and adjusts the setting screws of the business.
title: Der Baulöwe

description: Hearts is a card game. At the end of the game, the player with the lowest score wins. Your goal in each hand is to avoid winning any 'tricks' including a heart or the Black Maria (aka the Queen of Spades), or to gain all 13 hearts and the Black Maria. Hearts for Windows allows for 1 to 4 human players but is always a 4 player game either filled by human players or computer players. The only drawback to more than one person playing is all the human players cards are displayed on one screen, allowing for each player to see each others cards. The program allows for custom rule variations such as the Jack of Diamonds are worth -10 points, etc... The computer players randomly say silly comments.

sample_screenshots.caption: They're sticking me with the Queen of Spades, NO!
They're talking s*** after sticking me with the Queen of Spades...

title: Hearts for Windows

description: In Zombie Castle you hunt down the infamous Count Sukula in a monster filled castle. Along the way you must locate food, keys, hidden doors and breakable walls all while avoiding dangerous zombies, skeletons, vampires, and other creatures.

sample_screenshots.caption: Got that floating zombie head right between the eyes with my trusty crossbow!

title: Zombie Castle

description: Atomic is a freeware remake of the game Atomix, a timed puzzle where you have to assemble molecules from atoms, by sliding them in position in maze-like levels. There are 3 difficulty settings (plus practice mode) and 30 levels to complete (recreated from original ones).
title: Atomic

alternate_titles.description: Name used in the game documentation
alternate_titles.title: Win Aliens v1.01

description:
Aliens is a single player shareware game based on Taito's Space Invaders. As with the classic Space Invaders game the player has a canon which they can move to the right and left along the base of the game window. The canon fires upwards at the descending alien ships. This game varies from the original game in a number of ways:* Here there are no buildings to hide behind.

  • In another variation from the original game the alien ships land and steal the planets resources, these ships must be destroyed once they take-off as if they reach the top of the screen the players score is reduced.

  • Finally, the player must protect defending craft as they take-off. Shooting these down by mistake also reduces the player's score

The game is entirely keyboard controlled. The player's score is displayed in the game's title bar as the game progresses, there is no high score feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: Shareware version: This screen shows one of the defending ships taking off and firing at the aliens.
Shareware version: A game is underway. The player's score and status are displayed in the title bar.
Shareware version: This screen is displayed when the game loads.
Shareware version: This is the shareware reminder screen.

title: Aliens

alternate_titles.title: AnnaTommy: An Unbelievable Voyage into the Human Body

description: Anna and Tommy are explorers of the human body. They travel inside the body in shrinking ship called the Virtual Surgeon. Controlling the Virtual Surgeon, you'll go through the body, one system at a time, learning new things about each one along the way. But you only have a set amount of time to explore, and there are obstacles to hinder your advancement through each system. Take too much damage, or let the time run out, and it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game begins with a render intro. Pictured: the poor soul we have to enter
This mini-game is basically <moby game="Tetris">Tetris</moby> without the disappearing blocks
We navigate through the body by choosing the desired direction

title: AnnaTommy

description:
Avalon Casinos is a freeware game that contains the most popular games found in a casino. The games on offer are: American Roulette, French Roulette, Blackjack, Video Poker, Mini-Baccarat, and Pai Gow Poker.

The game has two modes of play, an on-line mode in which players register their credit cards and play with real money, and an off-line practice mode in which players use a virtual $2000.

There is no save feature in this game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The second set of gambling tables

title: Avalon Casinos

description:
Beetle Run is a single player, shareware, maze like puzzle game with an educational twist because at the start/restart of each level a beetle related fact is displayed.

The game is played on a 6x6 grid. In each cell are pieces of road or track which the player can rotate by clicking on them. The contents of the cells changes with each replaying of a level. The game starts with the beetle being positioned in one cell, from that point the player has six seconds before the game starts. The objective of the game is to keep the beetle moving for as long as possible.

Points are scored for each cell the beetle passes over, specific cells that score bonus points and, in later levels, there are special bonus paths. The player must attain a predefined level in order to progress to the next. The game can be speeded up and the when that happens the point scores are doubled.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level two has some new style squares
.... the game displays a beetle fact at the start of the level.
The game starts here but before it starts ....
The game loads and displays this screen. The beetle wanders around and disappears behind the company logo

title: Beetle Run

description:
Office Darts 301 is a single player freeware game which has been released on its own to generate interest for a larger game called Office Darts.

In this game the darts are thrown by a short backwards and forwards movement of the mouse and their forward and lateral trajectory is shown in two separate windows.

The game itself is straightforward, the player and the computer take turns to throw darts at a board and the first to reach a total of three hundred and one wins. The player can play against up to three computer players and the skill level of these players can be changed. This freeware version does not require the player to start or end on a double.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bust! A technical darts term for scoring more than is required.
A game in progress. Pulling back on the mouse generates a targeting ladder on the board. The flight of the dart can be observed in the top and side view windows
The player beat the computer and a 'Congrats Player!!' message is displayed
There is a game selection screen which is only of use in the full Office Darts game
The main game screen. Darts are picked up one at a time by clicking on them. At the end of a throw they are returned to their box by clicking on the 'Return Darts' button

title: Office Darts 301

description:
Blob Factory is a single player, freeware, side scrolling platform game.

The eponymous Blob, a blue circle with feet, was relaxing in his hot tub at the factory when something went wrong. His tub exploded sending him across the factory and now he must make his way back, avoiding toxic green slime and nasty robots along the way. The game is level based, each level ends when Blob reaches his blue hot tub. Blob cannot fight, the only controls are the left/right arrows to move him and the space bar to make him jump.There are cheat keys that allow the player to jump to the next level, clear a blockage or damage a robot. There is no high score screen, no sound and no save game.

The game's menu bar allows the player to adjust the speed, access the in-game help function, and start a new game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The start of a game. The help text contents and game information both open new windows.
Blob can move and jump. He cannot fight the robots.
Game Over means Blob has died. This triggers a  the display of this small window that overlays the game screen.
The game's help file opens in a new window that is a different size to the game window.

title: Blob Factory

description:
Brainwave is a single player shareware game that is a sort of cross between Space Invaders and Galaxian.

Though it looks like a space shoot 'em up the premise for the game is much closer to home. Nanobots have been surgically implanted into the player's brain to repair damage caused by watching too much television. However as they went about their work the nanobots achieved intelligence of their own and in order to survive they are now feeding on the player's brain. The good news is that the player's imagination has created a ship that will destroy the nanobots and so the battle commences.

There are nine scenarios in the full game with three being made available in the shareware release. This is a keyboard controlled game with the arrows moving the ship left / right and the space bar firing the ship's weapon. These is no up/down movement. Once a wave of nanobots has been cleared the game displays the player's score before presenting the next wave which the game claims to configure by analysing the player's game style. Some nanobots leave a power crystal behind that, if captured, upgrades the players weapons.

The game has sound, music, a high score table and re-definable keys.

sample_screenshots.caption: The action keys can be reconfigured. This option is accessed via the menu bar.
Game Over is a simple grey box like this.
The shareware nag screen that is shown on exit
The start of the Parieta scenario
This is wave one of the Occipitus level

title: BrainWave

description:
BrainWave 2 is a single player shareware game that combines the control system of Space Invaders with the swooping enemy formations of Galaxian. It is a sequel to Dexterity Software's BrainWave.

Once again nanobots are attacking the player's brain and the player's imagination has created a ship with which to fight them. Like its predecessor this is a keyboard controlled game with the arrows moving the ship left / right and the space bar firing the ship's weapon. These is no up/down movement.

When a wave of nanobots has been cleared the game displays the player's score before presenting the next wave. Destroyed enemy ships leave behind power crystals which, if collected, can be used to buy power ups such as more effective weapons, shields and special features before the next wave commences. With each successive level the enemy ships also evolve, getting power ups of their own making them harder to hit and giving them better weapons. The player starts with three lives, new lives are added for every 300,000 points scored. When a life is lost all the crystals that have been collected are lost.

The full game has three scenarios, only one of which is available in the shareware release. Some weapons and features are also available only in the registered release.

sample_screenshots.caption: In 2013 the shareware game starts with this warning that the game is out of date. This is not a problem as it still plays.
After displaying a brief, and optional, help screen the game progresses to this where the player has the option of buying the full game or playing the shareware version.
The shareware 'nag screen' that is shown on exit.
The end of the first wave and fifteen crystals have been collected. Time to go shopping!
Wave four is in play and this screen shot shows the newly purchased tractor beam automatically grabbing a nearby crystal.

title: BrainWave 2

description: Bricks is a single player, single screen, breakout clone with no sound, no scoring, and no special features. The player has three lives with which to clear the bricks on the screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is what the game looks like. There is nothing in the menu bar, no sound, no scoring.
Even when all the bricks have gone new balls keep on coming, the game just won't stop.

title: Bricks

description:
Diversions Slots is a single player shareware slot machine simulation.

In the registered version the player can play one, two or three lines for one coin per line but the shareware version was limited to just line one. Similarly the player can start with 100, 1000, or 10,000 coins with the shareware release being limited to just 100 coins.The player can save their game so that winnings are preserved.

This is an old school slot machine with no features, climbers, or jackpots.

The game can be controlled via the keyboard or via the mouse.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the slot machine. Apart from the help screen this is all there is to see

title: Diversions Slots

description:
Missile Attack is a single player variant of the classic Missile Command.

The game starts with a series of missiles descending from the top of the screen. The mouse cursor becomes a targeting sight and the player must position it in the path of the oncoming missiles and click a mouse button to trigger an explosion which destroys said missile. As the player progresses the missiles fall faster and become more numerous.

The object of the game is to defend the cities at the bottom of the screen as long as possible. The longer the game is played and the more missiles that are destroyed the higher the score.

This game is entirely mouse controlled.

sample_screenshots.caption: Wave three and by now Rome has been destroyed and the missiles are more numerous
The initial screen. A new game is started via the menu bar or the F2 key

Game Over.
London is destroyed and civilization comes to an end
At the start of the game there are relatively few missiles.
Wave four and just London and the anti-missile site are left

title: Missile Attack!

description:
Ms. Chomp is a single-player, shareware, Ms. Pac-Man clone for Windows.

As in the original game the gameplay is entirely keyboard controlled. Ms. Chomp races around a maze eating dots for points and dodging ghosts. In the corners of the maze are power pills that turn the tables. After eating one of these Ms. Chomp becomes the hunter and, for a short while, is able to eat the ghosts.

Points are scored when Ms. Chomp eats a dot, a ghost, or one of the items of fruit that appear in the maze. The player starts with three lives and additional lives are awarded for every 10000 points scored.

The game has a few sound effects, music - but only at the start, and a high score table. It plays in a window and there are game configuration options in the menu bar at the top. Game speed is adjustable by means of an "animation delay" number between 0 and 10000, where zero gives the fastest game

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's main menu showing some of the options available via the menu bar
The high score table opens in another window.
A game in progress. Ms. Chomp has just been got by a ghost.

title: Ms. Chomp

description: Quatra Command is a simple vertical scrolling space shooter, where a lone pilot has to investigate the Quatra sector, shooting at and dodging incoming starfighters. 10 levels of gameplay with increasing difficulty, collect health, photon and shield bonuses, player starts with three lives.

sample_screenshots.caption: Collect the bonuses that fly towards the top of the screen
Simple story for a simple space hero
That's it man, game over, man... Game over!

title: Quatra Command

description:
Prairie Dog Hunt Pro is a single player shooter. It is the third game in Diversions Software's Prairie Dog series.

Prairie dogs, genus Cynomys, are burrowing rodents native to the grasslands of North America. They are a pest and this game is all about blasting them as they run from burrow to burrow, a bit like a Whac-A-Mole game with guns.

There are two kinds of game play, the timed mode and the open season mode. Both are essentially the same but only the timed mode scores are added to the highscore table. The game has sound effects, sniper scope, variable game speed, a high score table and three difficulty levels. Aiming and shooting is mouse controlled but the keyboard is used to vary the scope's magnification.

The open season mode and the ability to change the size of the ammo clip are not available in the shareware version.

sample_screenshots.caption: Shareware version: The game's configuration screen, not all options are available in this release.
A timed game is underway. A prairie dog is visible to the right of the centre.
Shareware version: The game's menu screen
The game's high score screen showing the default values.

title: Prairie Dog Hunt Pro

description:
Prairie Dog Hunt Pro '97 is a single player shooter. It is the fourth game in Diversions Software's Prairie Dog series.

The North American burrowing rodents are still infesting the plains and grasslands and this game is all about blasting as many of them as possible. Gameplay is pretty much the same as in the previous game, Prairie Dog Hunt Pro where aiming and shooting is mouse controlled but the keyboard is used to reload and vary the scope's magnification.

The game still has three levels of difficulty and 360 degrees of fire, but now the graphics have been improved and the weapons have been upgraded to include a rifle, a shotgun, a laser and grenades. This version of the game has an optional wind element that can blow a shot off target.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's main menu has been updated to include both options and the high score table.
The Simulation mode shows compass points at the top of the screen
In the shareware version this nag screen is displayed on exit.

title: Prairie Dog Hunt Pro '97

description:
Star Merc is a single-player, first-person, space shooter from Diversions Software. The object of the game is to achieve a score high enough to be recorded on the high score table.

The player takes the role of a mercenary hired to keep the space lanes clear. This means dropping into sector after sector of space and destroying any ship that is present. The limitations are that the canon will overheat if overused and that each sector jump uses fuel which must be replenished by visiting a star base.

In combat there is the tactical scanner which looks like a red radar screen. This gives an indication of the position and number of enemy ships and, when combined with target direction indicators in the targeting window, help the player blast the bad guys.

The game is played out in the cockpit of the ship and is entirely mouse controlled. The mouse functions in two ways. In 'ship' mode moving the mouse steers the ship while the left mouse button fires the canon. The left mouse button toggles between this mode and 'cockpit' mode in which the player can select either the 'Eject' button to end the game or the 'NavTrack' screen in which the player selects the next sector to jump to.

sample_screenshots.caption: The in-game help text opens in a new window that replaces the game screen
The NavTrack screen where the player selects a new sector to jump to. On the right is a display showing how much fuel the player has and how much fuel is needed.
There aren't many game configuration options

title: Star Merc

description:
TZ-Minigolf is a shareware, top-down, golf game for up to four players. The game was released in full on a 'try before you buy' basis. Only the first six holes were playable until the player purchased a registration code. Once entered this code gave access to the full eighteen hole course.

This is not an accurate golf simulation, it is more of a 'desktop golf' or 'crazy golf' game. The game is entirely mouse controlled. The ball is placed on the starting pad via the mouse. The player then uses the mouse to determine the direction and strength of the shot, the further away the cursor from the ball the harder the shot.

There is music, sound effects and a high score table, the player can access these are available via the menu bar.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file is accessed via the menu bar and opens up in a new window obscuring the game screen
Starting a new game means entering players' names. Though the box looks big the game only allows nine characters
Hole six, the last of the shareware holes, is one of those holes that surprises.

title: TZ-Minigolf

description:
The Threshold is the second installment in the Reflux series of games. It continues the story of Frank Corwin a.k.a. "Flux", who at this point is forced to leave the Hong Kong Gui virtual world and return to the real world in an attempt to escape the mobster Big Mama Jama. Can he continue to elude the villain while his every move is being broadcast nationwide?!

The game is presented as a comic book of twenty pages. By clicking the panels, players can follow the narration from the characters' perspective, view digital video sequences or interact directly. Additional content and background information can be read in folders near the bottom of the screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: Another fine example combining comics with live action clip.
Live action clips are sometimes used to enhance the experience.
Frank is being chased. But why?
The combination of future virtual world hacking with wushu style art is unusual, to say the least.
The story is expanded with various notes and clips that you can read.

title: Reflux: Issue.02 - "The Threshold"

description:
You are MicroMan, stuck inside a computer. You must run, jump, and shoot your way out. Along the way are cannons, a variety of mechanized enemies, ladders, invisible bricks, three different weapon upgrades, a super jump ability, a shield, moving platforms, platforms that fade in and out of existence, transporters, a mirror room and bottomless pits.

MicroMan was made by the author of WAP (Windows Animation Package) in order to demonstrate the abilities of that WAP Windows 3.1 game engine. The game was so popular that the author went on to make the shareware release of The Adventures of MicroMan, which has completely new level designs.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game, game engine and author info screen.
Missiles and turret and platforms, oh my!
Big robot guarding the path ahead and the second power-up.

title: MicroMan

description: A Question of Vengeance is the first of two episodes of Castle of the Winds. For this release of the top-down role-playing game the first episode of the shareware game released as a retail title. This release can be run directly from the floppy disk by just typing 'GO'.

sample_screenshots.caption: There's lots hidden away under the menu bar
An extensive help file accompanies the game. The Overview section can be accessed from the title screen. It can be accessed from within the game too
Aha! We've discovered our home farm, or what's left of it, and we've advanced the story
After all the neat buildings this one stands out, wonder why
The character creation process. The blue bar on the extreme left shows the available distribution points. It decreases as the attribute sliders are increased

title: Castle of the Winds I: A Question of Vengeance

description: Lifthransir's Bane is the second of two episodes of Castle of the Winds. For this release of the top-down role-playing game the second episode of the shareware game released as a retail title. This release can be run directly from the floppy disk by just typing 'GO'.
title: Castle of the Winds II: Lifthransir's Bane

description:
Les récrés d'Henri Dès is a series of educational games, each one with a different theme. This one is about witches and ghosts.

Endorsed by Henri Dès, a French language children's singer and songwriter well-known in french-speaking countries, the CD-ROM features many games (matching games, educational games about musical instruments) based on Henri Dès' songs.
title: Les récrés d'Henri Dès: Sorcières et Fantômes

description:
Chinese Solitaire is a single player card game.

Superficially the game resembles Klondike solitaire in that some of the cards are face up and they are built into sequences of descending rank and alternating colour.

Forty-nine cards are dealt into seven stacks of seven cards. The first four stacks are dealt face up, the remainder have three cards face down and four cards face up. Cards can be moved between the stacks either singly or on blocks, the only rule being that the card selected must be placed on a card of the opposite colour and one higher in rank - so a seven of hearts could be placed on the eight of spades for example. An empty stack can only be filled by moving a king into it.

The object is to transfer all the cards to the foundations building from ace to the king, the author states that with practice this can be achieved in around one hand in three.

The game has no undo feature, no hint feature, and is played entirely with the mouse

sample_screenshots.caption: The unregistered version loads with a reminder to purchase the game clearly visible
All game configuration menus are accessed via the menu bar
There is no undo feature and no hint feature in this game so when the player is stuck there's no option but to restart
The game is played with the mouse. Once a card has been clicked on it can be dragged and dropped into place
The game area and the card backs can be changed. The changes don't take effect until the next hand is started, or this hand is re-dealt.

title: Chinese Solitaire

description:
Crazy Eights Deluxe is a single player card game in which the player takes on the computer.

At the start of the game each player is dealt seven cards. The remainder of the deck is placed between them and one card is placed face up. A player can play any card onto the revealed card if it is the same suit, the same number or if it is an eight.

If the player does not have a suitable card in their hand they must take a card from the deck and continue doing so until they do have a card they can play.

The object of the game is to be the player who plays all of their cards at which point the cards in the opponents hand are totalled and become the winning player's score. The match ends when one player scores more than two hundred points.

The game is played entirely with the mouse. The registered version has two levels of difficulty, expert and novice and a save game function.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file opens in a new window that's fixed in size but which can be moved around the screen
This is the game area and card layout. It's turn based and instructions are shown in the centre of the screen.
The game configuration option, ordering options and help screen are all accessed from the menu bar.

title: Crazy Eights Deluxe

description:
Trap Shooting is an arcade game of shooting at targets (clay pigeons).

First, let's have a look to the Configure menu. Select the difficulty of the game (Easy, Moderate or Hard). No surprise Hard mode is the fastest. From this menu you can also enable or disable sound effects, using the check box. Here we go now, playing with the mouse : right click to toss the clay pigeon into the air, then, aim the crosshairs and left click to fire at the target. A round ends after 25 targets.

Two last things: the registered version has no 'nag screens' ; running on recent computers, the game is way too fast, even in Easy mode. So consider using a slowdown utility.

sample_screenshots.caption: an incentive to register, remove this nag screen

title: Trap Shooting

description: Backgammon is computer backgammon conversion of the classic board game. The game allows the player to chose between three different difficulty level. The gameplay offers standard rules in comparison to the original board game. The additional features are: option to undo a move, enable double cube, repeat opponent's move, suggested move. The game allows you to play only a with the computer.
title: Backgammon

description:
The game recreates the Battle of Gettysburg, the pivotal point of the American Civil War. Player takes a role of General Meade or General Lee as the supreme commander against a simulator that takes into account different variables that affect the outcome of a battle - terrain, morale, stamina, ammunition, aim, and more. Historical factors that hindered soldiers in the 1860s, such as poor communication or slow-moving artillery, are also reflected in play.

66 brigades fought for the Union and 52 brigades fought for the Confederacy are present in the game. Player directs the marches, issue orders to cavalry, infantry, and artillery to engage the enemy, entrench in key positions, and bombard strongholds in the real time. Four playing speeds are offered. The speeds correspond to the number of seconds that the battle simulation uses to represent one minute of the actual Battle of Gettysburg. The game's objective is to see if the battle may be fought better than it was in the real life. If player takes the Confederate side, see if Lee can win. If player fights for the Union side, see if Meade can preserve more lives while still holding the position. The performance will be reviewed at the end.

sample_screenshots.caption: Lee's Bold Plan as an Introduction to the game
Selecting the side in Historical Play

title: Gettysburg: An Interactive Battle Simulation

description:
This title is a CD-ROM compilation of the content as follows:

  • Bicycle Blackjack
  • Bicycle Poker
  • Bicycle Baccarat
  • Bicycle Roulette
  • Bonus - Interactive Guide to Poker Tells
title: Bicycle Casino: Blackjack, Poker, Baccarat, Roulette

description:
This is a collection of four Humongous Entertainment games on one CD, packed in with Creative and Acer hardware, circa 1995. One of the kits that is included on this disc is the Creative Sound Blaster Discovery Plug and Play multimedia kit.

  • Let's Explore the Farm
  • Putt-Putt Joins the Parade
  • Freddi Fish and the Case of the Missing Kelp Seeds
  • Putt-Putt and Fatty Bear's Activity Pack
title: Humongous Entertainment Collection

description: Dodger is a game in the style of Pac-Man. In Pac-Man the player has to eat all the dots from the board in order to pass to the next level. In this game the dots are replaced by fruits (apple, strawberry and cherry) that the player has to eat in order to get a score and to go to the next level. The enemies are four mean laser machines in the sides of the levels and they attack the player by shooting lasers. When the character is hit, a life is lost. Unlike Pac-Man there are no special pills in the game. The board also contains skulls and they also make the character lose a life upon contact. After every level a password is provided to continue playing from that level immediately.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 4: Be careful from the lasers
Level 6: Be careful from be upon contact with skulls

title: Dodger

description: Fruit-Picker is a simple action game where the player moves a goblin around the screen, and must collect all the fruit while avoiding flying bees. Contact with a bee causes the goblin to lose a life. A bee disappears every time the goblin collects all of a specific type of fruit.

sample_screenshots.caption: The goblin basks in its failure, looking awfully happy.
Title screen, with the dancing goblin.
The goblin basks in its success.

title: Fruit-Picker

description: The Hunchback of Notre Dame is an amateur platform game, loosely based on the 1996 Disney movie of the same name. The player controls the hunchbacked Quasimodo who, on each level, must collect five tambourines and then head to the exit. Collecting a bangle gives the player an extra life. On his way, the player is menaced by soldiers, jugglers, skeletons, and the evil Judge Frollo himself.

sample_screenshots.caption: The first level. Wait for the patrolling soldier to vanish in a door.
Game over: Quasimodo, Esmeralda and the murderous maniacal acrobat are arrested.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

description:
Lunacy for Windows is a single-player, shareware, puzzle game. The game is reminiscent of Pipe Mania! in that the player has to guide a spark along electrical wires from a start point to an end point. However In this game the player does not add new pieces of wiring to the puzzle, instead the wiring is already in place and the player rotates it at the node points to make new connections or to break others.

Additionally there are special nodes, some of which speed up the spark, some which cause it to burn the wires it passes through so they cannot be re-used and some fixed nodes that cannot be rotated at all.

All puzzles are timed. The game has a high score table which holds the ten best scores. The game is played entirely via the mouse.

sample_screenshots.caption: In game help can be accessed via the menu bar. As is customary for games of this era the help text opens in a new window which covers the game screen
A game in progress. The spark started in the green node in the upper right and must be guided to the red node in the lower left. The node in the extreme lower left is being rotated
The game's title screen. A new game can be started either via the menu bar of via the Start Game button
This is a shot of the in-game help can be accessed via the menu bar. As is customary for games of this era the help text opens in a new window which covers the game screen

title: Lunacy for Windows

description: Laserstrike is a single-player, shareware, puzzle game. The object of the game is to fire a laser at a target and hit it twice to complete a level. Lasers can only travel in straight lines and so the player must use lasers and other canons to move blocks and mirrors in order to achieve the task. The full version of the game has twenty two puzzles and seven coaching or tutorial puzzles.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the message the player sees when they successfully complete a level. There is no automatic advancement to the next level, the player selects their puzzle manually
This shows the kind of puzzle the game contains. It is taken from the PC Plus version of the game.
The full version of the game has twenty-two levels
The game's title screen, full freeware version
The game's title screen, PC Plus version. The game was released as shareware and special customised versions were included on magazine cover mount CDs

title: Laserstrike

description:
25 Jahre Mondlandung: Die Apollo-Missionen is an encyclopedia about the race to the moon. There are six categories (history, technology, the Apollo missions, persons, moon and legacy) which lead to a overview with links to the topics. Those are covered with texts and in some cases with additional pictures and video snippets. Otherwise there is a main index as well as a multimedia index giving direct access to videos and pictures.

The game portion of this programme is a trivia quiz which covers manned spaceflight. The player has to answer questions in multiple choice and is rated based on the amount of correct/wrong answers and the time.
title: 25 Jahre Mondlandung: Die Apollo-Missionen

description: Made with Klik & Play by the author of Scoop Da Poop, this game represents a quiz with three questions about Reality-on-the-Norm characters. In case of any wrong answer the game starts from the beginning until it will be finished successfully.
title: RON Quiz Part 1: Section A: RON Characters

description:
Battles in a Distant Desert is a single player, shareware, wargame set during the war in Iraq.

The player has limited resources with which to complete three scenarios which the game documentation describes thus:* "Berm Busting" - Your company is charged with the mission of securing this sector of the berms and hold it until the oncoming units of Bear's "Hail Mary" push, arrive to pass thru you.

  • "The Streets of Khafji" - Command the infantry and artillery defense of this northern Saudi resort town as the Iraqis attempt to storm and take control of the town. Or control the Iraqi attack and see if you can hold Khafji.
  • "The Az Zibayir Road" - The war is lost for the Iraqi Army in Kuwait, and the escape is underway. Led by elements of the armored divisions occupying Kuwait, the Iraqi Army attempts to return to Iraqi with great amounts of equipment and plunder.

The shareware version of the game gives the player only the 'Berm Busting' scenario.

sample_screenshots.caption: Every game ends with a 'Victory Report'
Many options are accessed via the menu bar, this is the in-game help file
The game ends in a shareware nag screen
An in game screen showing a US helicopter attacking Iraqi troops

title: Battles in a Distant Desert

description:
Columns is a single player, Falling block puzzle which describes itself as being based on Macintosh Columns by Chris Christensen which, this game claims, was itself based on XColumns by Jay Geertson.

The game consists of blocks which themselves consist of three coloured squares. All blocks are the same shape but the coloured squares they contain will vary. The player can position the blocks with the left/right keys, rotate the coloured squares within the block with the up key, and drop the block with the down key. The object is to align the colours so that three or more in a vertical, horizontal, or diagonal line are all of the same colour, when this happens they flash and disappear causing the squares above to drop down. The process repeats until either the player gets bored or the screen fills up.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game plays in a small window. All other options such as help text and game information open in small windows too
The game has a high score table

title: Columns

description:
The Game of the Amazons is a one or two player, freeware conversion of the Argentinian board game El Juego de las Amazonas.

The object of the game is to capture territory, the player who controls the most squares at the end of the game wins.

The game is played on a 10x10 chessboard where each player has four pieces that move like queens. The rules are quite simple, a piece may move to any legal square, provided the path to that square is not blocked. Once it arrives in the target square the piece must fire an arrow one or two squares in any legal direction. The square where the arrow lands is then claimed by that player and locked. Once a square is locked neither player nor their arrows can travel over it.
Players take turns to move their pieces and the game ends when one player is unable to move and the player holding the most territory wins.

The game is entirely mouse controlled and the computer opponent has three skill settings, there is also an undo feature and a save/load game feature.

Though this is a complete game that was released as freeware there is/was a registered version with more features that could be purchased, furthermore for a small fee players could receive game updates as and when they became available.

sample_screenshots.caption: A game in progress showing how the move history is recorded and how blocked squares are depicted.

The start of a game. 
This also shows the player selecting whether the human or the game plays as white and what skill level the AI opponent will use

The game has a help file that is accessed via the game's menu bar. It opens in a new window. 
This screenshot shows the game's description

Game Over and white wins.
The black Amazons can no longer move so the game is over. The unclaimed squares belong to White because they can still play and take them.

title: The Game of the Amazons

description:
Knight's Tour is a single player, freeware game.

The player is given a chessboard onto which they can place a single knight. The object of the game, which is more of a puzzle really, is to cover every square of the board once and once only making only moves which are legal for this chess piece.

The game has options to count the number of moves made or to show all available moves.

sample_screenshots.caption: At any point the player can turn on the function that shows the sequence number of each move. This is a menu bar option
At any point the player can turn on the function that shows the available legal moves. This is a menu bar option
The game plays in a very small window. All messages appear in even smaller, separate windows.

title: Knight's Tour

description:
Euchre is a card game played by two teams of two players each. It is found mainly in Canada, from the mid-west to Nova Scotia, the U.S., from the mid-west to the north-east, the U.S. Navy, Britain, mainly Cornwall, Devon and the Channel Islands, Australia and New Zealand. It is played with the ace, king, queen, jack ten and nine of spades, clubs, diamonds and hearts and, in Britain, Australia and New Zealand, one joker. Full rules can be found here.

This implementation of the game is a single-player, freeware version where the computer takes the role of the other three players, it is the North American variant of the game in that it does not use Jokers. The 'freeware' version of the game is complete but has just one difficulty setting, that of Novice. The registered version of the game, which had to be purchased, promised an 'Advanced' level.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game has a decent help file that is accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window that overlays the game area

Game Over!
The game is played in teams of two and the player's team has been successful

The start of a freeware game.
The boxes on the right show the skill level 'Novice' and though it looks as though this can be changed, in this version 'Novice' is the only option

The game is underway.
Whenever a trick is won the words 'I Win!' appear

The start of a game.
The card backs can be altered

title: Euchre

description:
Smoke'em Poker is a single player, freeware game based on five card draw poker. It is played entirely with the mouse. The game is between six players with the computer playing five hands, each hand of five-card draw proceeds as follows:* ante and dealing

  • opening bets (no minimum hand to open)
  • discarding cards (1 discard of up to 3 cards)
  • closing bets
  • the showdown (where you win, lose, or tie)

If a computer player runs out of money they are eliminated, if the player runs out of money they can either abandon the game or sit back and watch to see which AI player wins. The game can be customised, the AI players can be given a skill level, specific name and gender or the game can assign these randomly. The game rules can be also be customised as can the alter the initial cash amount and the betting limits.

Earlier versions of this game had been available on the Amiga but v1.5 is the earliest Windows game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game has good documentation which is accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window.

When the player is dealt their hand they can check the odds on the kind hand they can expect to make.
This opens in a small window that floats over the game area
A couple of hands into the game and it's the player's turn to bet. Only three bets are possible, these are the default values which can be changed in the game's configuration settings
The first round of betting has completed and four of the AI opponents have folded. Now it's the player's turn to draw

The first hand is over and the human player lost.
The player must click on the 'Deal' button to get the next hand

title: Smoke'em Poker

description:
School-Mom for Windows: Volume 1 - ColorBook is an educational colouring game for young, pre-school, children. It is designed to be run on a computer in "Kid Mode" so that curious little people cannot access anything they should not see, it is the first product in the "School-Mom' series that was intended to "take your child from his/her first introduction to a computer to college-level concepts."

This product contains pre-drawn pictures that the child can colour in, drawing tools so that they can create their own masterpiece, and a 'book' where their pictures can be saved, it also supports printing. To make the game more interesting to young ones each action is accompanied by a musical sound, for example each colour in the palette has an associated musical note.

The freeware game contains forty dinosaur related pictures, add-on package each with forty pictures, one of which was Egyptian themed, were available for purchase.

sample_screenshots.caption: The player's pictures can be saved and viewed in a book that's all their own
There are basic shape and colouring tools that can be used to construct a picture

title: School-Mom for Windows: Volume 1 - ColorBook

description:
Solitaire King: Beleaguered Castle is a single player card game, in this game the player is estimated to have a one in four chance of success.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrive arrange all four suits in an ascending sequence. The game starts with the four aces being arranged in the centre of the game area, the remaining forty-eight cards are made into eight groups of six cards and are placed with one group on either side of each of the four aces. All cards are placed face up, overlapped and exposed within groups. Cards are moved one at a time. Any card can be moved onto the pile in the centre as long as it is of the same suit as the original ace and it follows in sequence. Likewise any card can be moved onto another row if, regardless of suit, the card it is moved onto is one higher in sequence - so a ten can be moved onto a jack and later a nine can be moved onto the ten etc.

The game contains two variations. In Street and Alley the aces are not placed in the centre when the game starts. The player deals the full deck in four rows of seven and four rows of six and an ace is only moved to the centre as it is released. The other variation is Citadel, here the aces are shuffled into the body of the deck but as they are encountered in the deal they are placed in the centre as are any subsequent cards that can be placed on them. So in this variation if the Ace of Hearts was discovered early on in the deal then when the Two of Hearts is dealt it would be placed on the ace immediately followed, if possible, by the Three and Four etc should they be discovered in sequence.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

The start of a 'Street and Alley' game.
The Ace of Clubs was free and has been moved to a foundation. The other aces remain trapped
The start of a game, standard variation.
A nice clear freeware notice is displayed at the start of the game
The option to switch between the game variants is accessed via the menu bar
The game has a help file that is accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window

title: Solitaire King: Beleagured Castle

description:
Solitaire King: Busy Aces is a single player card game, it is rated one of the easier games to play with about a 1 in 4 chance of success.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a two standard decks of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange all eight suits in an ascending sequence. The game starts with twelve cards being place face up in two rows of six. The player works through the deck of cards moving aces onto the foundation cells as they become available. The twelve cards that are placed face up are used as bases onto which other cards can be moved if they are of the same suit and one lower in rank.

In the standard game the player can only play through the stockpile of cards once and once a card is moved to the foundation pile it stays there. However there are two variations available to the player via the menu bar, one allows them to re-use the stock pile and the other allows cards to be brought back from the foundation into the build area.

The player scores two points for cards moved to the foundation but loses one point for each card turned over from the stock pile and ten points for reusing the deck should that option be enabled.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

The game's title screen follows the freeware declaration

title: Solitaire King: Busy Aces

description:
Solitaire King: Grandfather's Patience is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a two standard decks of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange all eight suits in an sequence, one sequence in each suit starting with the Ace and ascending to the King and another sequence for each suit running from the King through to the Ace.

The game starts with twenty cards being dealt face up. If they can be placed on one of the foundations then this is done first and vacant piles are replenished from the stock pile. These twenty cards form the build area but each position can only hold two cards at a time.

In this game the player can only play through the stockpile of cards once and once a card is moved to the foundation pile it stays there. There are no variations in this game that make it easier

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

title: Solitaire King: Grandfather's Patience

description:
Solitaire King: King Albert is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange all four suits in an sequence starting with the Ace and ascending to the King.

The game starts with all the cards being dealt face up. There are seven rows of cards, the first containing one card, the second containing two and so-on, these form the build area. In addition there is a row of seven cards dealt separately to the build area which are referred to as 'The Belgian Reserve'.

At any time any card can be moved to the foundation provided it is of the same suit and continues the sequence running from the ace to the king. Single cards may be moved from one column to another provided they form a descending sequence and the suits alternate red/black (or black/red)

In the standard game once a card is moved to the foundation pile it stays there. There is a variation to this game that make it easier, this allows cards to be moved back from the foundation to the build area and it is enabled via a menu bar option.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

description:
Solitaire King: Kitty In The Corner is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange all four suits in an sequence of the same colour starting with the Ace and ascending to the King.

The game starts with all the aces being dealt face up in the centre of the play area. The player then deals cards singly from the stock pile playing cards directly onto the foundations started by the four aces or onto one of four piles or tableau which in this game are called 'kitties', (the 'kitties' are arranged in a rectangular formation hence the name 'Kitty in the Corner'.)

The standard game is to build sequences of the same colour, this game has a variation to the rules which allows the player to build the sequence by suit, it is enabled via a menu bar option.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

description:
Solitaire King: Maze is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange all four suits in sequence starting with the Two and ascending to the King.

The game starts with all the cards being dealt face up in four rows of eleven and one row of ten then all the aces are removed. This leaves six spaces, cards are moved around the play area by filling a space with a card which continues the same-suit ascending sequence (view from left to right) with the card on either side of it.

There are no variations to this game.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

description:
i>Solitaire King: Monte Carlo is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

This is a matching pair game which is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards. Twenty cards are dealt face up in four rows of five cards, the remaining thirty-two cards are held in the stockpile and the object of the game is to clear this pile. Cards are removed from the twenty made available if the deal by matching adjacent pairs (horizontal, vertical or diagonal) of the same rank. When all pairs have been matched and removed the spaces are filled in by closing up the remaining cards and then dealing cards from the stock pile.

The game has a couple of variations which are accessed via the menu bar. One option is to match pairs which match on both rank and colour, in this variant the cards do not have to be adjacent and the second option changes the way the spaces are filled from the stock pile.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

title: Solitaire King: Monte Carlo

description:
Solitaire King: Shamrocks is a single player card game.

This game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange the cards in four suited ascending sequences, from ace to king.
The cards are dealt into seventeen fans each containing three cards, this leaves one card free which forms a pile on its own. Fans/piles containing a king have that card moved to the bottom, aces are moved to the foundation cells when they are the top card of their pile. The player moves cards between the piles forming descending sequences, e.g. an eight can be placed on a nine of any suit, the restrictions being that only the top card of any pile can be moved and no pile can contain more than three cards.

The allows a rule variation which is accessed via the menu bar, this permits cards to be moved between the fans in either ascending or descending sequences.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

title: Solitaire King: Shamrocks

description:
Solitaire King: Sly Fox is a single player card game.

This game is played with two standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange the cards in four suited ascending sequences and four suited descending sequences from king to ace.

The cards are shuffled and twenty cards are dealt in a five by four rectangle on either side of which are the four foundations on which the sequences are built. The player starts by moving any cards they can to the foundations, when this has been completed the first twenty cards from the stock pile are taken to form what is called a buffer, turned face up one at a time, and placed somewhere on the twenty piles in the game area - they may not be placed onto the foundations. When all cards have been placed onto the central piles the player may once again begin transferring cards to the foundations in sequence. When no more cards can be transferred the player repeats the process with the next twenty cards and so on until all cards have been dealt.

The game has a variation which can be enabled via a menu bar option which makes the game easier to complete, this allows the player to place cards directly to the foundations when taking cards from the buffer.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

title: Solitaire King: Sly Fox

description:
Solitaire King: St. Helena is a single player card game.

This game is played with two standard deck of fifty-two cards and the object is to arrange the cards in eight suited ascending sequences from ace to king.

The cards are shuffled and twenty cards are dealt in four overlapping rows of ten cards, this is called the tableau or the build area, with the remainder being placed in a stock pile. Across the top of the screen are the eight foundation cells where the aces are placed and the sequences are built. Cards can be moved from the build area to the foundation if they follow both in suit and in ascending sequence. Cards may be moved between rows if they follow in suit and descending sequence. Cards taken from the stockpile can be added to the foundation or any of the rows provided they follow the same rules otherwise they are placed on a discard pile.

The game has two variations which can be enabled via a menu bar option which makes the game easier to complete. The first allows cards to be moved from the foundation sequences back into the build area which gives the player more options when trying to complete and join sequences. The standard game does not allow a redeal, the second variation allows one redeal of the discard pile.

The player scores two point for cards moved to the foundation but loses one for each card turned over. Ten points are lost should the waste pile be redealt, all scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

description:
Solitaire King: Triplets is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards dealt in sixteen groups of three and two groups of two. The player can play any cards that are on the top of their group which they do by selecting three cards in ascending sequence regardless of suit, e.g. seven-eight-nine. The player can also treat the sequence of cards as though it 'wraps around' and is continuous so queen-king-ace, king-ace-two, ace-two-three are all valid sequences.
The objective is to play remove all the cards from the game area

There are no variations to the rules of this game.

The player scores one point for each triplet eliminated but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

description:
Solitaire King: Trusty Twelves is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards. Twelve cards are dealt in three rows of four, this is the build area, the remaining forty cards form the stock pile.

The game starts with the player assessing the twelve cads before them looking for descending sequences irrespective of suit. They make as many of these as possible which creates spaces in the build area which they fill from the stock pile one card at a time. These cards too are used to create new sequences or add to existing ones. The object of the game is to successfully place all the cards from the stock pile into sequences in the build area.

There are no rule variations in this game.

The player scores one point for cards moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse
