description:
Solitaire King is a single player card game comprising thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The full product consists of the following games: Aces Up, Accordion, Auld Lang Syne, Beleaguered Castle, Busy Aces, Calculation, Canfield, Clock Solitaire, Famous Fifty, Gaps, Golf Solitaire, Grandfather's Patience, Help your Neighbor, King Albert, Kitty in the Corner, Klondike, Maria Louisa, Maze, Monte Carlo, Poker Solitaire, Pyramid, Royal Marriage, Shamrocks, Sly Fox, Spider, St. Helena (Forty Thieves), Sultan, Take Eleven, Triplets, Trusty Twelves, and Yukon.

It was customary to for developers to advertise their products by publishing a limited or crippled version of it to attract potential buyers. With Solitaire King the developers released some of the titles as freestanding freeware games. This in itself is not unusual, what is unusual is that they released so many. Thirteen freeware games were identified when this submission was first made and many more have been found since, according to this source, as many as twenty-four of the games were released in this manner.
title: Solitaire King

description:
Solitaire King: Yukon is a single player card game.

This title was of a number of freeware games that the developer released to promote interest in the full product, Solitaire King which had thirty-one different games and over eighty variations thereof.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards. The key thing about Yukon is the deal which the documentation described thus, deal a row of seven cards faced down, then deal the second row of six cards overlap the top of the existing cards starts from the second column to the left, then deal five cards starts from the third row, then four, then three, then two, and finally one on top of the seventh column. Turn up the top card of each column. Deal the rest of the twenty-four cards faced up four at a time, on top of the first six piles, with cards in each row overlapping but exposing the previous row.

The object is to move all the dealt cards to the foundations and create four suited ascending sequences running from ace to king. This is done by moving cards around the columns arranging them in descending sequences of red/black, or black/red.

There is one rule variations in this game which allows cards to be moved from the foundations back into the game area.

The player scores one point for each card turned over and another for each card moved to the foundation but scoring stops as soon as the player uses the Undo or Load a saved game options.

The game has save/load and undo/redo functions but has no sound and no statistics are kept. It is played entirely with the mouse

There is only one available variation to the game's rules.

title: Solitaire King: Yukon

description:
Brickbat is a single player, freeware, moving block puzzle game.

The game window consists of two parts. The lower part is a wide low picture wall, there are six to choose from, and the upper part is used by two flying 'brickbats' one good and one bad. When the game starts the image in the lower part of the screen is converted to blocks and scrambled. Using the arrow keys and the spacebar the player manoeuvres the good brickbat to pick up blocks and drop them into position to reassemble the original image. While they are doing this the bad brickbat is also moving blocks around randomly as well as trying to kill the player's good brickbat by dropping blocks on them, who can do the same to him which makes him disappear for a short while.

The game is entirely keyboard controlled and it records the top one hundred best completion times.

title: Brickbat

description:
Button Madness is a single player, freeware, puzzle.

The game is played on a 4x4 grid using the mouse. The basic game starts with all the cells coloured red, when the player clicks on a cell it and some others change colour to grey. The object of the game is to turn all the cells grey. For a more difficult challenge the player can either elect to start the basic game with the cells scrambled or they can choose the difficult setting.

There is no high score table, no sound and no save/load function

title: Button Madness

description:
Code Breaker is a single player, freeware version of the classic, code breaking game Mastermind.

Game-play is virtually identical to all other Mastermind clones, the player has to deduce the correct four colour code and has ten attempts to accomplish this. In response to each guess the player is told how many colours in the right position and how many colours in the wrong position were present in the attempt. There are three difficulty settings, very easy - which uses just four colours, average - with six colours, and expert with eight colours.

The game is played entirely with the mouse.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game opens in a small window.
The game has a single window of player information. It opens in a new, separate window

A successful conclusion to a game. 
As soon as the player clicks on 'New Game' the game area is reset

By clicking on a cell repeatedly the player can cycle through the colours. 
In this game white is counted as a colour
There are three levels of difficulty. These are accessed via a menu bar option

title: Code Breaker

description:
Spider is a single-player, freeware, card game.

This game is played with two decks of cards. All the cards are dealt face down in ten columns, when this is done the last card of each column is turned over. The object of the game is to arrange the cards in descending suited sequences, from king to ace, such sequences when formed are removed from the table.

The player may only move one card at a time and it can be placed on any column but it must be placed on a card which ranks one higher. Where the player establishes a run of cards in the same suit all, or part, of that run may be moved but again it must be placed on a card which ranks one higher that the highest card being moved.

The game has an unlimited undo feature but no save/load function.

sample_screenshots.caption: The player must use this drop down menu box to real the second, and subsequent, round of cards
This is how the cards are dealt at the start of the game
The game has a single help window which opens up over the game area

title: Spider

description:
This compilation includes:

  • Leisure Suit Larry in the Land of the Lounge Lizards
  • Leisure Suit Larry 1: In the Land of the Lounge Lizards (remake of the above)
  • Leisure Suit Larry Goes Looking for Love (in Several Wrong Places)
  • Leisure Suit Larry III: Passionate Patti in Pursuit of the Pulsating Pectorals!
  • Leisure Suit Larry 5: Passionate Patti Does a Little Undercover Work!
  • Leisure Suit Larry 6: Shape Up or Slip Out!

sample_screenshots.caption: After the installation you can choose a desired part from this menu. Mind the nice idea of putting the evolving Larry character alongside of each title!
LARRY: Collector's Edition Autorun Menu. Not much to choose from but hey - you get all of the games installed at once!

title: Larry: Edycja Kolekcjonerska

description:
Forty Fives! is a single-player, shareware, card game.

The game is also known as Forty-Five, Forte Fives, Auction Forty-Fives, Auction 120s, 120, Growl, Spoil Five, Maw and Strong Fives. It is a trick-taking card game for two to six people which originated in Ireland and is said to be well known in Eastern Canada. This computerised version of the game is played by one player against the computer and is based on rules common in the Merrimack Valley area of Massachusetts and its surrounding area.

Briefly the object of the game is to score one hundred and twenty points, the first player to reach this number wins the game. In each hand the players are dealt five cards, each player then takes it in turn to bid for trumps. The highest bidder wins and names trumps, they also get the opportunity to discard weak cards from their hand and replace them with cards from the kitty. Both players also get to discard unwanted cards and draw unseen replacements from the deck. Players then play cards and attempt to win as many tricks as possible.

This game has a comprehensive help file explaining the rules, scoring and principles of the game, it also has an optional tutor mode which the player can use while playing a game to aid them in their play.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's statistics. These are cumulative and can be cleared if they look really depressing.
Another hand. Here the computer has won the bidding phase
There are small help files that cover specific subjects
The player can review the cards played at each trick
The game tutor gives strategy advice to help the player improve their game.

title: Forty Fives!

description:
In Banania, the player takes the role of Berti who works as a garbageman in a warehouse with 51 floors. Unfortunately an escaped monkey fled into the warehouse and left a lot of banana peels behind. Now Berti's job is to move through all floors and clean up.

To reach all banana peels, Berti has to solve Sobo-Ban-style puzzles: shoving around boxes to create new ways. Boxes can't be pulled, so it is important to think ahead in order to avoid unsolvable situations. There are two kinds of boxes: one which need a free place behind them and others which allow to push all other boxes (including the first kind) behind them at once. Other obstacles are doors (require finding a key) and two monster types which kill Berti on touch: dumb ones which can be trapped with boxes and smart ones which can push boxes themselves.

Berti has unlimited lives and the current level can be instantly reset. There are two movement options available (either Berti moves automatically in the pushed direction until he reaches a wall or the stopping button is pressed or the player has to press the movement button for each step) and the game counts the used steps for use on the high-score list.

sample_screenshots.caption: When pushing the blue boxes, the main character Berti is not restricted to only one box.
The green monsters may not be smart, but are still deadly.

title: Banania

description:
APBA presents: Baseball for Windows is a baseball simulation based on the board game APBA Baseball and an updated re-release of the 1993 version of the same name. The gameplay is focused on simulating single matches by using statistics which are kept for every athlete. The player's input is making decisions for every step of the match, e.g. how a pitcher should act. There is also the option to create custom teams and leagues.

The two main additions to this version is voice commentary by Ernie Harwell (a long-time radio baseball commenter) and the option to import athletes from Bill James Electronic Encyclopedia (a Major League Baseball database on CD-ROM).
title: APBA presents: Baseball for Windows

description:
The Big 3 is a turn-based (three turns per year) wargame set in World War II. The player has the choice between three factions (USA/Britain, Soviet Union and Germany/Italy) with the goal of winning the war. The presentation is similar to other wargames: abstract symbols are moved over hexagonal fields.

This game focuses on macro-management: The playing field (Europe, Northern Africa and a small part of the USA) is one big map divided in relatively few hex fields (e.g. Germany has five). During each round, the player produces units (restricted by force pools which ensure that each faction keeps a certain ratio of unit types) and moves units. Combat is decided with a dice roll while factors like seasons influence the winning chances. Producing units and offensive actions require building and military points which are awarded at the end of each round, e.g. by holding cities. It is important to keep supply lines.

This is an updated version of The Big Three specifically developed for Windows 3.x. Besides VGA graphics and adapted menus, the main addition is an AI opponent to play against.
title: The Big Three

description:
Mind Grind is a one or two player quiz game.

The player selects a character from one of several that are supplied, most are aliens, and competes over five rounds:* The Matrix of Knowledge: This takes place on an 8x8 grid and to advance to the next level the player must connecting four cells in any direction: horizontally, vertically or diagonally by correctly answering the question that they contain.

  • The Pillars of Wisdom: Here the player must advance to the topmost level of pillars and they may jump one or two ranks at a time. The difficulty of the question is determined by the level of the jump attempted.
  • The Maze of the Mind: Is a randomly generated labyrinth containing forty-five 45 locked doors. The player must navigate their way out of the maze by answering questions to open these doors. Question difficulty will increase as competitors progress further into the maze
  • Platforms of Insight: The player(s) stand in a tube. Beneath them are stacked platforms containing question topics. Answering a question correctly removes a platform while answering one incorrectly adds a platform. Too many wrong answers will see the player crushed against the top of the tube.
  • Looking For Signs Of intelligent Life: This is the final level and it sees the player piloting a space ship towards earth. To reach their destination the player must dock with ten space stations and answer the questions they ask correctly. Getting a question wrong means being flung into hyperspace.

In both one and two player games there are bonus points for being the first to complete a stage and options to spend some points/dollars, for example in the final level there are meteors and such to be avoided along the way so spending points to buy a deflector shield may be a worthwhile investment

sample_screenshots.caption:
Looking For Signs Of intelligent Life
Here the player must answer questions at each of ten space stations en-route to Earth

Here the player is part way through the first challenge.
The answered questions are shown by concentric red squares.
The question topic of a square is revealed when the cursor hovers over it

Platforms of Insight
Platforms are removed by answering related questions correctly

There is in-game help available. This opens in a new window
Demo version

title: Mind Grind

description:
WinSwim is a single player card game based on the game "Schnauz" that is popular in the southern regions of Germany. The real game is a four player game but in this implementation the computer takes the role of three of the players.

Players have three lives plus a final chance. The game is played by swapping the cards in the player's hand with those in the centre of the table, the object being not to have the lowest scoring hand at the end of the round because the lowest scoring player loses a life. The last remaining player wins the game.

sample_screenshots.caption:
Here Player 1 has lost all three lives and is 'swimming'. 

Shareware version played on a WIN 98 machine

Players draw cards to see who plays first. After that they are dealt three cards each and the more are placed face down in the centre
Shareware version played on a WIN 98 machine

The player can change the patterns used on the deck of cards, but only in the registered version
Shareware version played on a WIN 98 machine

Three honour cards in a suit is a very good hand to have

Shareware version played on a WIN 98 machine

Players take turns exchanging cards from their hand with the cards in the centre
Shareware version played on a WIN 98 machine

title: WinSwim

description: Crispy is a Solitaire card game variant. The object of the game is to place the face cards on the edges while removing all nonface cards a pair a time. Kings go on top and bottom, queens go on the sides, and jacks in the corner. If the face cards are all in valid edge positions and all other cards have been removed you have won the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the middle of a game.
Starting a new game in German.

title: Crispy

description: This unofficial add-on disc contains mor than 200 levels for Command & Conquer: Red Alert.
title: C&C 2: More Missions

description:
Let's make it simple : 4 Play is a Windows 3 version of the classic Connect 4 game.

Start by choosing the type of game being played (human vs computer, human vs human, or computer vs computer) then who goes first. You can even give names to the players, or use default ones (red for human, yellow for computer). You can also set in the "Options" menu the computer search depth, to any value from 3 to 9. The default value is 4. Then the game can start : to make a "move", simply click on the slot you want to place a piece in.

The game is shareware but not crippled at all.

sample_screenshots.caption: last screenshot for release information, to be deleted
I won without cheating at all !
Game in progress. Will I win ? (I play red)

title: 4 Play

description:
Attaxx is a single player, shareware board game that plays just like the arcade game.

Each player starts with two pieces which are located on the corners of a 7x7 grid. Players take turns to move a token either one or two fields (diagonal moves are allowed); if the piece is moved on a field which borders on the original field, a duplicate piece is created.
When one or multiple of the opponent's pieces adjoin the new position, they are converted to the player's colour. Moving is mandatory (unless there is no legal move possible) and the match is over as soon as all fields are filled up. The winner is the player who has more pieces on the board at this point.
Some fields on the board may be blocked off, these appear as a solid black cell in the grid, and a single player can compete against AI opponents of varying difficulty.

The game is played entirely with the mouse, it keeps score of the games in a session but has no high score table. The starting board layout may vary with each game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Al alternate starting layout and a new computer opponent
The game credits and shareware reminder

The board at the start of a game
The black cells are inaccessible and change position from one game to the next
The game can be configured via the menu bar

title: Attaxx

description:
Stradiwackius is a musical counting book. It is the second VroomBook created by T/Maker Company, and the first original story to be created in the VroomBook series.

The Inter-activator is still the same as in Four Footed Friends, except the fourth language is German rather than Japanese. Albert has interesting facts about musical instruments, while Wendy shows the child new words and how the instruments notes sound like, and Pablo allows the child to colour a picture from the story or build a wacky instrument. There is also a parent guide which shows the use of the software on the CD-ROM.
title: Stradiwackius: The Counting Concert

description:
This CD-ROM combines two educational storybooks into one package:

  • Four Footed Friends
  • Stradiwackius: The Counting Concert
title: Four Footed Friends / Stradiwackius

description: Logic Quest 3D is one of the first 3D critical thinking games by The Learning Company. Players are greeted by a Raven, who guides the player with some help along the way. Players sign in and choose either the courtyard (easier challenges) or the castle (harder challenges). They can also create their own levels using the built-in level editor. The recommended age group is ages 8-14. Players use their critical thinking and problem solving skills to complete the quest.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the level editor, where you can create your own challenges.
The main menu has access to the challenges and the level editor.

title: Logic Quest 3D Adventure

description:
A Day At The Races is a shareware, horse racing game for up to four players.

Each player starts with $100 and places bets in fixed amounts on any of the eight houses. Once the player(s) have selected their horse, chosen the amount to bet and decided whether the bet is win, place or show the race can commence. The horses race across the screen and the winnings, if they are any, are paid.

sample_screenshots.caption:
The game screen
Players can select their bet through a menu bar option or the side bar
The end of a race and the published results
The game's help text opens in a new window

title: A Day At The Races

description:
MVP Backgammon is a single player, shareware, mouse controlled backgammon game.

The game has a save/load feature, in game instructions, and customisable AI opponents, or evaluators as the game calls them, which play a beginner, intermediate and expert game. Additionally, in the registered version, the player can play tournaments, wager, and customise the in-game sound, music and graphics

sample_screenshots.caption:
The load screen
After a few seconds the game opens a shareware reminder window

Starting a new game
In the registered version the player can create their own identity but in the shareware version they play as Anonymous

The game's help file opens in a new window
In this screen you can almost hear the frustration of the game's support team

title: MVP Backgammon

description:
Crusade in Space is a single player, mouse controlled game of space exploration and conquest.

The game starts by displaying a series of short sentences, one at a time, on the screen. "Finally. The people of your world are under one ruler. YOU The Emperor! Now your scientists have given you spaceflight. Your armies are training for planetary invasions! An entire galaxy awaits your rule! As you begin your CRUSADE IN SPACE". All of which neatly sets the tone for this strategy / resource management game.

The player takes control of a small fleet around a single star in a big galaxy. The object of the game is to build more and bigger fleets, strategize, and conquer it all. Planets can be tasked to produce ships, troops and planetary defences. Fleets can be ordered to attack nearby systems and once the opposition is defeated in space transports can be sent to conquer the planets.
In game time is based on a stardate system which can be frozen or sped up as required. This enables the player to send fleets across large distances, or construct capital ships quickly in real time.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here the planetary factory is being tasked with building a StarCruiser

Selecting a planet in tactical view brings up the planetary control menu
Clicking on the '?' icon brings up screen specific help
This is standard to all screens

Here the task force is being given a destination
The player selects DESTINATION in the upper left tactical box. Then assigns the target via the status bar at the bottom
The game starts by displaying a series of short sentences ending with this

title: Stardate 2140.2: Crusade in Space

alternate_titles.title: Bubble / Quaak: Zwei fesselnde Geschicklichkeitsspiele für Windows

description:
Bubble / Quaak is a compilation of two exclusive games:

  • Quaak is a Frogger variant. The player has to guide a frog over a street without being run over by the vehicles and then over a river with floating tree logs. The current level is successfully finished when five frogs were guided to safety
  • Bubble is a platformer with 25 one-screen levels. The player controls a bubble who navigates the levels, e.g. by jumping and climbing ladders, in order to collect all treasure. It is also important to avoid static obstacles like scissors. This game has a level editor.
title: Bubble / Quaak

description:
Noddy: The Magic of Toytown on a CD-ROM is an educational game divided into five parts :

* the Interactive Storybook : wile discovering an interactive story filled with surprises, the child will develop its reading skills

* tour Toytown in Noddy's car to collect lost items. It's all about recognition and counting skills

* the movie theater : just watch two Noddy films

* the games : with the first one, listen carefully to sounds then find out "Who Said That" ! Second game : with Bert Monkey, just match two cards. Last game in this section is a maze game : first choose a maze then, look for letters and items.

* in Tessie Bear's studio, children will develop their creative skills with 3 activities. With "Cartoon Collage", they will create their own cartoon story. With "Invisible Paint", a picture appears twice, but with some differences. Spot them ! Last activity is the "Artbox", which is a painting activity.
title: Noddy: The Magic of Toytown on a CD-ROM

description:
ABM Command is a single player Missile Command clone for Windows.

The game can be played with the mouse or the keyboard where the player has separate action keys for each missile station.

sample_screenshots.caption: At the end of each round the player's score is shown
As the game progresses the missiles come down faster and then, of course, the player runs out of missiles

title: ABM Command

description:
Defender is a single player, Windows port of the classic arcade game.

The gameplay is virtually identical to the original. Players fly over a mountainous side-scrolling landscape attempting to prevent aliens abducting people. When enemy ships are destroyed the people they were carrying must be collected before they plummet to earth. Above the game area is a radar view of the game area so that the player can see where the enemies are and anticipate their arrival. The game gets progressively harder as the player moves up through the levels with later levels forsaking the earth altogether and being conducted in space against swarms of aliens.

This game has some interesting features not usually found, for example the game can record and play back the last successful game, it can display the CPU resource usage, it also allows the player to configure the sound, the display and the controller

sample_screenshots.caption: The game comes with a pre-populated high score table
We've rescued another falling person, now to put them down safely and collect the bonus
The typical blocky explosions are here, just like the original
When the player completes a level their score and accumulated bonuses are displayed before the next level starts
One kind of alien craft leaves these small red homing mines behind when it explodes, they are very hard to shake off

title: Defender

description:
Defendroid is a single player, Windows port of the classic arcade game. It is an updated, renamed version of Glen Summers game Defender.

The gameplay is virtually identical to the earlier version but the graphics have been updated, the game has been renamed, and a new help system has been introduced.
Players fly over a mountainous side-scrolling landscape attempting to prevent aliens abducting people. When enemy ships are destroyed the people they were carrying must be collected before they plummet to earth. Above the game area is a radar view of the game area so that the player can see where the enemies are and anticipate their arrival. The game gets progressively harder as the player moves up through the levels with later levels forsaking the earth altogether and being conducted in space against swarms of aliens.

This game has some interesting features not usually found, for example the game can record and play back the last successful game, it can display the CPU resource usage, it also allows the player to configure the sound, the display and the controller and to create and configure patch files that affect the look and feel of the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game comes with a snazzy help file that's accessed via the menu bar
Those pink cube things leave a trail of mines behind them
The controllers can be configured, these are the default keyboard controls

In space the player faces swarms of aliens
These multi-coloured ones are kamikaze ships, they swarm and collide

title: Defendroid

description:
Here They Come is a single player, shareware, shooter

The game is similar to Space Invaders in that ranks of enemy ships traverse the screen getting lower on each pass and occasionally a bonus ship appears at the very top of the screen. Unlike Space Invaders however the player has no buildings to hide behind and they are not limited to just left and right movement.

The player has three lives and the object is to score as highly as possible. When a life is lost the game resets and starts at the beginning of a wave.

sample_screenshots.caption:
There is an in-game help option
This is a shot showing the game's controls
The game starts with a shareware reminder

This is the game. When the aliens are wiped out they just reappear
The current high score, top right, is held by Emily - the game was written for her (see credits)

The game configuration options
The sound box is greyed out if a driver is not detected

A new high score has been achieved.
the default name used by the game is Emily - the game was written for her (see credits)

title: Here They Come!

description:
Hurricane is a one or two player, shareware, keyboard controlled shooter based on the Atari game Tempest.

As in the original the game uses wire frame graphics to represent a well from which spider like creatures ascend. The player moves around the 'top' of this well zapping the creatures as they climb. Once they reach the top of the well it's just a matter of time before they catch the player who then loses one of their three lives. The registered version of the game grants smart bombs after level fourteen.

The two player game is a 'hot seat' game with players taking turns at the keyboard, they do not necessarily play on the same wire frame. The game has sound and a high score card, the action keys cannot be redefined.

Here the player has just lost a life. The game prepares them before restarting

These are the game's instructions
They are accessed via the game's menu bar

title: Hurricane

description:
Mega Peril Snake is a one or two player, shareware implementation of Snake

The shareware version has twenty five levels, the registered version has another hundred plus a level editor. The game is entirely keyboard controlled and has no high score table. In addition to food for the snake the game area the game area can have other features including teleports and direction controllers

sample_screenshots.caption:
The start of a game.
There's no scoring in this game
The food is the pink blob below and to the right of centre

That's not fair!
I ate some food and grew into my own tail!
The game is entirely keyboard controlled and the action keys can be redefined
The game has a help function that is accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window

The game's 'real' title screen has snakes running around in the background
There are lots of configuration options in the menu bar

title: Mega Peril Snake

description:
The Onyx Arcade II is a compilation of four simple (but compilation-exclusive) games designed to be playable in a window using a fraction of the screen.The games are: Bio Buster*, a kind of Space Invaders / Whac-A-Mole hybrid

  • Asteroid Clash, a vertically-scrolling shooter
  • Eat. Yom., a horizontally-scrolling dodge-'em-up
  • and Astro Phong, an elaborate riff on Pong.

All of the games have simple keyboard controls, moving along an axis with the Ctrl and Alt keys with the Shift sometimes used for a second function.
title: Onyx Arcade II

description: Based on the movie adaptation from 1994, Lassie MovieBook is a computer game combining an interactive storybook with full-motion video clips, hotspots with QSound 3-D audio, bookmarking, and letting the computer read the story out loud. Clicking on a filmstrip will show a clip from the movie, and as a bonus at the end of each chapter, players put together a jigsaw puzzle by answering questions based on what they have read from that chapter. The game features reading comprehension, and is targeted to ages 3 and up.

sample_screenshots.caption: The first chapter of the story.
Title screen. When the game is played at a higher resolution, the player's desktop is displayed in the background.
Here is the first page. Notice that there is a page curl at the bottom right hand corner of the book, and by clicking on it will go to the next page of the story.

title: Lassie Interactive MovieBook

description: Based on the movie adaptation from 1994, The Secret Garden MovieBook is a computer game combining an interactive storybook with full-motion video clips, hotspots with QSound 3-D audio, bookmarking, and letting the computer read the story out loud. Clicking on a filmstrip will show a clip from the movie, and as a bonus at the end of each chapter, players put together a jigsaw puzzle by answering questions based on what they have read from that chapter. The game features reading comprehension, and is targeted to ages 3 and up.
title: The Secret Garden MovieBook

description:
Amazing Truckology is a children’s computer game created by Ezekial S. Jackson that teaches children about a variety of trucks. There are four places to explore: the farm, fire station, the quarry, and the building site. Fifteen trucks are included in the game. There are also clickable hotspots in some of the scenes. There are some video clips and animations that shows the player the trucks on how it does and how they work. There are colour photographs on every truck included in the game, as well as some technical information.

Four Truck-A-Rama VR scenes are included in the game, as well as 3D animated models of the fifteen trucks included. The player can also simulate driving one of the fifteen trucks in the game as well. The game features background music which has 40 minutes of songs included. Amazing Truckology is suitable for ages 5 and up.
title: Ezekial S. Jackson's Amazing Truckology

description:
Game Gallery Vol.#2 is a collection of shareware, charityware and freeware titles from Micro Star (Europe). Though this is a collection of Windows games the installation program runs in DOS and allows the player to transfer any individual game or any combination of games to their hard drive. It also gives the player the option to preview the game before installing it by running it from the CD.

The games in this package are shown below in alphabetical order though in the product's menu they not grouped or well ordered at all. In the following game list a description or qualifier has been added where the game is not on the database at the time this submission was prepared, where the game is on the database only a link to the existing database entry is supplied. The games are:* 3D Tic Tac Toe: from Chris Aldrich at UNH Robotics Laboratory

  • Accordian Solitaire: a solitaire game, this time from Richard R. Sands
  • Slam!: renamed Air Hockey in the menu system
  • Air Strike: the first level of a three level shareware shooter from Alston Software Labs
  • Alien Force
  • Bang! Bang!
  • Battle Sat
  • Blitzer
  • Box World is a single player, crate moving, puzzle game from developer Jeng-Long Jiang
  • Brain Cubes: a puzzle from Lithuanian developer Michael Dvorkin
  • Brain Jam another solitaire card game
  • Cheezi a Pachesi variant from Paul T. Dawson
  • Comet Busters! just called 'Comet' here
  • Concentration: the single player memory card game, this time from Gerald Hogsett
  • CuBIC: a Rubik's Cube puzzle from Geoffrey S. Chappell
  • Daleks
  • Fifteen: a strategy game from Russian developers AQUA Enterprises

  • Fences: a strategy game from Steve Blanding Fortress: a turret shooter from Diversions Software

  • Hearts for Windows: renamed just 'Hearts' here

  • Hurricane
  • Kye
  • Hearts for Windows: renamed just 'Lucas' here
  • Maze Master: from Fred George
  • Merlin: The Quest for the Wand: a turn based exploration game from Carl Bjork
  • MicroMan
  • NCC-1701: a Star Trek variant
  • Noughts and Crosses: called 'Ox' in the menu
  • The Greatest Paper Airplanes, just called Paper Airplane here, is not a game but instructions on making paper planes
  • Patuman: a single player Pac-Man variants
  • Peg Puzzle: a shareware implementation of the traditional board game
  • Paulie Python
  • Prarie Dog Hunt 2: Judgement Day: a shooter from Diversions Software
  • Puzzle 1: from Idle Time
  • Quatra Command
  • Reversi: this is Microsoft's game for Windows for Workgroups v3.11
  • Search and Destroy!: a Battleship game from Randy Baron
  • SkiFree: this is another Microsoft game
  • Stellar Explorer: another Star Trek variant
  • Solitaire Golf: a single player charityware card game from Steve Laterra
  • Solus: another Peg Solitaire game. This time from Yorgo Vergos
  • Taipei
  • Take One: the third Peg Solitaire game. This one's from EirSoft
  • Tank Tracker: a shooter from Albert C. Ashton
  • The Greens
  • Thieves and Kings: a solitaire game from Paul DeWolf
  • Tiles and Tribulations: a puzzle game from Technological Computer Innovations
  • U.F.O. Tracker: another shooter from Albert C. Ashton
  • Warheads for Windows: a Missile Command game
  • Wa-Tor for Windows: a strategy/simulation game based on predator/prey relationships from Kovach Computing Services
  • Windows Command: a Missile Command game from Timothy G. Baldwin
  • Windows Solitaire: another solitaire game, this time from John A. Junod
  • Windows Wizard: Not strictly a game, more a 'Magic 8 Ball' which gives spoken yes/No answers
  • Wintrek: a Star Trek variant by TSoft
  • Winvade: entitled 'Winvaders' on the menu this is a Space Invaders game from Peter C. Finch
  • Wordwiz: not a game but a 'word puzzle composer'
  • Worm War: this is a Centipede style game
  • World Empire II: This is a strategy game from Viable Software Alternatives

sample_screenshots.caption: In Preview mode most games run in a small window that partly overlays the menu
The Installation menu allows the user to install multiple games at once
The help text for the game preview/install process really just states the obvious, but it does so in a new window

Not all the games run directly from the CD and some that do run don't run that well.
This is clearly expected
The CD does not autoload. The user runs an installation program and sees this screen, they may either preview the games by playing them from the CD or install them

title: Game Gallery Vol.#2

alternate_titles.description: Used in the DOS installation process title
alternate_titles.title: White Wolf Software: Windows To The World
Windows To The World: 75 Great Windows Programs

description:
Windows to the World is a compilation of shareware/freeware games and software. The software installs as a series of 'packs', pack's one to five can be run from the CD while packs six, seven and eight must be installed on the hard drive. Each 'pack' is installed separately and creates a separate program group.

This CD contains the following products:* Pack 1:

Bow and Arrow a simple shooter by John Di Troia,

Confound Game an implementation of the board game by Pete Koziar,

Squeeze Play a crate moving puzzler from company="Henderson Graphics">Henderson Graphics,

Super Craps a mouse controlled casino game from Chris Peterson of Texas,

Tail Gunner a shooter from Diversions Software,

Tiles and Tribulations: a puzzle game from Technological Computer Innovations

Emlith, MacBlaster, Missile Attack!, Ms. Chomp, and Slam!

  • Pack 2:

Brain Cubes: a puzzle from Lithuanian developer Michael Dvorkin,

Peg Puzzle a monochrome implementation by Oscar Waddell,

Pipe Dream a Windows 3.x version by Scott Thompson

MLC GuessIt! a hangman game from the Minnesota Literary Council,

Hop aka "Windows Hop-Over Puzzle!" by David A. Feinlab,

KenoPro by Dennis Pipes,

Chomp, Get the Girl!, Hurricane, and MicroMan

  • Pack 3: Bridge For Windows: An implementation of the card game by David Fullerton,

Destroyer For Windows: A Battleships game by Don E. Krafcheck,

PaiGow Poker For Windows: A poker game by Chris Straghalis,

Prarie Dog Hunt 2: Judgement Day: a shooter from Diversions Software,

Runner: A puzzler / strategy game from SouthBay Software of Torrence, California,

Stellar Explorer: a Star Trek variant,

WinChess: This game by "David Norris has 13852 positions in the opening book,

Alien Force, Hexxagon, Bang! Bang!, and a New Testament viewer.

  • Pack 4:

Box World: A crate moving puzzler from Jeng-Long Jiang,

CardShark Hearts: A version of the popular card game from Nelson Ford,

EmPipe: A Pipe Dream variant,

Gold Hunt: A treasure hunting game,

Hangman For Windows from Pocket-Sized Software, this looks like an earlier version of their Hangman 2,

Player's Blackjack from MRK Interactive,

Watzi for Windows: A freeware Yahtzee game from JTC Software,

Simon, Hyperoid, Comet Busters! and 4 Play

  • Pack 5:

BlackJack For Windowsfrom John Washburn,

Fortress: a turret shooter from Diversions Software,

Hearts for Windows: Another version of the popular card game this time from Paul Padriana,

Roulette: From Canadian developer A. J. Withers,

Sheepshead: A solitaire game Video Draw Poker Challenge: Video poker that can be played as tens or better, jacks or better, or Jokers wild,

Worm War: This is a Centipede style game,

Zanti: A Pipe Dream variant guiding alien ants from their spaceship along the path of peace,

Paulie Python, Jewel Master, Columns

  • Pack 6:

Tank Tracker: a shooter from Albert C. Ashton,

World Empire III, Castle of the Winds I: A Question of Vengeance,

Screen Peace: A screen-saver manager; Sieze The Day: a desktop calendar program; Three drawing packages: Paint Shop Pro, Leonard's Sketch and SmartDraw!; Crystal Walls: A Windows 3.x wallpaper changer and screen saver; and Address Manager a self explanatory non gaming title

  • Pack 7:

Space Interceptor : An Asteroids game,

Super Concentration: The trusty card game without which no compilation is complete,

Hexxagon: A single line slot machine game,

Ecneuqes: A strategy game played with two decks of cards,

CuBIC: a Rubik's Cube puzzle from Geoffrey S. Chappell, WinPoker v3.0: A video poker game with seven variations,

Nitemare-3D, Warheads for Windows and GNU Chess 3.21

  • Pack 8:

WinFish: A fishing game and WinCheck a home finance, non-gaming title.

Where a game in the above list is already present on the database at the time this entry was created a link has been provided, where the game is not present additional text has been added to prevent confusion with any similarly named game.

title: Windows to the World

description:
Game Gallery Vol.#1 is a collection of shareware, charityware and freeware titles from Micro Star (Europe). Though this is a collection of Windows games the installation program should be run in DOS. It gives the player the option to preview the game before installing it by running it from the CD. The installation process allows the player to transfer any individual game or any combination of games to their hard drive.

The games in this package are shown below in alphabetical order though in the product's menu they not grouped or well ordered at all:

  • 4-Play
  • Admirals Command: A Battleship game
  • AlienTic
  • Backgammon from Graphics Software Labs
  • BattleGrid: Another Battleship game

  • Black Dog Cribbage a card game by Black Dog Software
  • Blackout a puzzler by Zarkware
  • Block Breaker
  • Bow and Arrow a simple shooter by John Di Troia
  • Brain Games For Windows
  • Bridge For Windows: An implementation of the card game by David Fullerton

  • Combat Tanks

  • Dominate: A strategy game based on Go

  • Double Block: A two player version of Concentration

  • Football: A game based American Football from the Texan company TSoft
  • Gradiator: A Lunar Lander game
  • Halloween Match: a kind of blind poker game using themed pictures
  • Hang Man: from the Texan company Burnham Park Software
  • Hyperoid

  • Klotz

  • Lander: there are af few games named Lander, this one is by George Moromisato

  • Mazemaker
  • Missile Attack!
  • Ms. Chomp
  • Nine Men's Morris from Carl von Blixen
  • Nuts! a freeware puzzle game using numbered hexagonal nuts
  • Sea Battle: a Battleship game from Russian developers AQUA Enterprises
  • The 21 Cardtrick for Windows, not really a game
  • WinChess from David Norris
  • Win Fight
  • WinPong: puts bouncing balls on the desktop
  • Win Slot from BFM Enterprises
  • WinTrek 2.0
  • WinTris: another Trtris clone from Kipnis Enterprises
  • WinWheel: A Wheel of Fortune game from Russell Mueller the chap behind EGAWHEEL & VGAWHEEL
  • Yacht is a Yahtzee game from developer Frank Bielsik
  • YATC another Tetris clone

  • Zanti: A Pipe Dream variant guiding alien ants from their spaceship along the path of peace

Where a game in the above list is already present on the database at the time this entry was created a link has been provided, where the game is not present additional text has been added to prevent confusion with any similarly named game.

sample_screenshots.caption: In Preview mode the player can only select one game at a time and they are warned that it may not play properly when run from the CD
After prompting for the CD drive letter and the install folder the user is given the option of installing or previewing the games
The install process allows multiple games to be installed, however there is no 'Install All' option, the games must be selected individually

title: Game Gallery Vol.#1

alternate_titles.title: Multimedia Pool: Step into the ultimate multimedia pool hall

description:
Multimedia Pool is a pool game that offers 4 game modes: Eight Ball, Nine Ball, Bumper Pool and Straight Pool, all available in practice mode, against the computer, or against another player. When playing against the computer, the player can choose between 5 skill levels.

The strength and angle of the shot are adjusted using the mouse or the keyboard and the project balls path (a line drawn from the cue ball to the target) can be turned on or off. Games can be saved and loaded at any time.

Some unusual options let you change the magnetism of the balls, the tilt of the table (making balls drifting downwards) and even the gravity (pick between the Earth, the Moon, Jupiter or Planet X - a strong gravity planet in a worm hole).

The help file provided with the game also includes a history of pool games and game techniques.
title: Multimedia Pool

description:
Cheese Terminator is a Sokoban clone, a top-down puzzle game where the player, controlling a mouse, must push all the pieces of cheese onto target squares, and only one piece of cheese can be pushed at a time. The game contains 50 levels. It's possible to choose to play any level with the "Practice Level" option. By choosing "New Game" from the menu, the player begins a scored game, starting from level 1 and advancing to the next level when the last one is completed. While in this game mode, the player can restart the current level at the cost of one life; running out of lives ends the game, and allows the player to enter his name into the high score table, recording the level he reached and the total number of moves he made.

Other features include undoing the player's last move by pressing Backspace, and a "boss key" (F10) which immediately minimizes the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The window that shows up after completing a level
First level. Push all pieces of cheese onto the dots
Level three is more complicated. At the bottom we see the counters for moves and lives

title: Cheese Terminator

description:
The game contains 4 mini-games representing main events of the baseball match:

  • Batting Practice to strike a thrown ball with a bat;
  • Fungo Fielding to catch the flying ball;
  • Sign Calling 101 to memorize the couch's movements and to repeat them in proper sequence;
  • Umpire Arguing to make the umpire angrier without getting ejected, selecting the various statements.

Successful player's actions are rewarded with points, and players with more points are enlisted into High Score table distinguished by three difficulty levels. In-game help allows the player to understand the rules of the game more precisely.

sample_screenshots.caption: Ready to strike a thrown ball with a bat
Memorizing the couch's movements to repeat them in proper sequence

title: Time Out Sports: Baseball

description:
This is obviously a compilation of:

  • Les Guignols de l'Info...Le Jeu !
  • Les Guignols de l'Info: Le Cauchemar de PPD
title: Les Guignols de l'Info...La Totale !

description:
Franklin’s Reading World is an educational computer game for ages four to seven that teaches reading skills featuring Franklin The Turtle, based on the Kids Can Press book series from Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark.

Educational features include: phonics, reading, spelling, vocabulary and word recognition. There are eight scenes included in the game, which includes over 300 words with three levels of difficulty. The player can explore Franklin’s World and can click on the words to hear the pronunciation. There is also a 40-page sentence book where the player can print out and colour.
title: Franklin's Reading World

alternate_titles.title: Swift Classics: Card Games For Windows

description:
Card Games is a compilation of nine card games. A single install process loads all the games together and the player accesses them via the Windows Start menu or their program group depending on which operating system is being used.

In this collection are the games:

  • MVP Bridge Lite
  • MVP Cribbage Deluxe
  • MVP Euchre Deluxe
  • MVP Hearts Deluxe
  • MVP Spades Deluxe

The games have AI opponents with customisable skill levels and support internet play. The package comes with four solitaire games which, when added to the games listed above, makes up the nine advertised games. Also included are four bonus solitaire games so in all the player gets these games: Canfield Solitaire, Friday the 13th Solitaire, Frog Solitaire, Golf Solitaire, King Albert Solitaire, Klondike Solitaire, Pyramid Solitaire, and Vanishing Cross Solitaire, which together comprise the eight games in the RISS Solitaire 8-Pak.
title: Card Games

description:
RISS Solitaire 5-Pak is a shareware collection of five solitaire games; Golf, Klondike, Frog, King Albert, and The Vanishing Cross. The Golf Solitaire in this game is a unusual, it plays the same as most other Golf solitaire games but it is played over nine holes.

When the games install they appear as separate games within Windows, each with it's own user guide that opens in a new window. All games allow the player to change the background colour but not the backs of the card etc. The games have an undo feature that undoes a single move at a time, they have no save game function and, other than recording the current best score in Golf solitaire, keep no statistics.

sample_screenshots.caption: Golf Solitaire: This game is played over nine holes. The current score is shown at the bottom of the screen.
Klondike: The player can change the background colour and the speed of play but that's all. There are no alternate card backs
A game of Vanishing Cross solitaire
Golf Solitaire: The menu bar for each game gives the player access to a user guide for that game. This opens in a new window.

title: RISS Solitaire 5-Pak

description:
MVP Euchre Deluxe is a single player, mouse controlled, trick taking card game in which the player competes against three computer opponents. It can be played over a LAN or the internet and these games are for four players.

This implementation of the game allows the player to customise the rules, change the background and the backs of the cards and turn the sounds & music on/off. There are nine AI opponents each with their own personality three for each level of expertise.

sample_screenshots.caption: At the end of each hand the score is shown
The end of game score. Stats like these are maintained so the player can see how well they did and with whom

When the game first starts up it asks the player to set up a player id.After that this prompt can be suppressed
In the background is the game's title screen

title: MVP Euchre Deluxe

alternate_titles.title: Top 20 Solid Gold Games For Windows
Top 20 Solid Gold: 20 Action Packed Games!

description:
Top 20 Solid Gold is a compilation of games from Cosmi Corporation, it re-uses a title that Cosmi had previously used for a Commodore 64/128 compilation and naturally has a completely different set of games.

In this compilation most of the games have been developed by Cosmi themselves and many appear in other compilations such as Top 30 Games 4 Kids while this entire compilation is included in the 201 Solid Gold Games collection. The games in this compilation are:

  • Battlegrid: mouse controlled Battleship game
  • Bloxs: a Tetris clone
  • Chess: an uncredited game with save/load features and customisable AI strength. Games can be limited to a specific time or number of moves, specific boards can be set up with the edit feature, and the player can play as white or black and can switch between the two mid-game.
  • Crazy Eights: this is a version of the popular kids card game
  • Great Walls: this is a Breakout game that plays in a small window
  • Hex Trap: this is a Minesweeper game but it uses hexagons instead of squares
  • Juggler: in this game the player has a paddle which they can move left/right and the object is to keep balls in play, it's a bit like a Breakout game but without the block bashing element
  • Killer Bees is a single-player shooter
  • Labyrinth: this simulates the game where a player tilts a board to manoeuvre a marble around a maze avoiding holes
  • Lock Out: this is a game where the player manoeuvres their blue marble and attempts to capture territory while avoiding other marbles. It is similar to earlier games such as JezzBall
  • Meteor Storm: this is a Missile Command style game where the player has a single base with which they must protect their city from meteors and UFOs it is entirely mouse controlled.
  • Maze-O-Mania: this game is based on Labyrinth, the difference being that the player uses a mouse-controlled magnet to manoeuvre their marble. the game has three levels of difficulty and the polarity of the magnet can be changed so that it can repel or attract
  • Space War: a space shooter game which is similar to both Planetoids and Space Guard. The spaceship can be controlled by either the keyboard or the mouse, and it has both missiles and shields additionally the gravity of the planet can be used to arc missiles towards their opponent. The game has three levels of difficulty and optional sound
  • Planetoids: an Asteroids style game which is basically Space Guard but without the 'defend the planet' element. The spaceship can be controlled by either the keyboard or the mouse, it has three levels of difficulty and optional sound..
  • Rollem: A Yahtzee variant in which the player completes three scorecards all of which count towards their total score
  • Slots: a basic slot machine game. The player starts with $10 and can bet in 25 cent increments from 25 cents to $1.50
  • Space Guard: this is an Asteroids style game where the player has to protect the earth, it is mouse or keyboard controlled and has three degrees of difficulty
  • Tanks: here the player tries to defeat enemy tanks on a block strewn grid. It is controlled by either the mouse or the keyboard.
  • Tractor Beam: in this game, which looks and plays very like Space Guard the player's space ship has to avoid asteroids and scour space for red rocks which are the scare element Linoleum 236, they then activate their tractor beam and tow the rocks to earth
  • Trails: This is a keyboard controlled Light Cycle style game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Planetoids is essentially an Asteroids game with space rocks and aliens
Slots or Slot Machine is a simple gambling game. The player can vary the stake by clicking on the coin that's above the coin slot, and the play by clicking on the handle
Planetoids is based on the game Space Guard

The start of a game of Chess.
This game plays in a window around 504x348 pixels in size, it does not scale when played full screen
Space War's help file opens in a new window

title: Top 20 Solid Gold

description: BattleGrid! is an implementation of the game Battleship. This game is played on two 10x10 grids, it is mouse controlled and can be played as a computer vs computer, player vs computer, or player vs player game. Players place their ships on the grid and then take turns 'shooting' at the opposing grid trying to find and sink their opponent's vessels. The game is customisable and allows players to take up to five shots per round each.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game plays in a window. Game configuration options are accessed via the menu bar.

The placing of ships is nicely handled
The game does not scale well to larger windows on later operating systems, this was played under WIN 98.

The shooting phase
vessels are only revealed when they have been completely destroyed

title: BattleGrid!

description: Bloxs is a single-player, freeware, keyboard controlled, Tetris clone. Initially when the game starts it fills the screen with multiple windows. There is a window with Keyboard help in it, another with the top ten scores, another with game statistics, a look ahead window showing the next block, and an information window with the version and release date in it. Any or all of these can be toggled on/off via the menu bar.

sample_screenshots.caption: Initially the game starts with lots of daughter windows. These can be positioned around the screen or toggled on/off as required

title: Bloxs

description: Crazy Eights is a single-player implementation of the children's card game. This game was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. This is a straightforward implementation where the only customisable option is a choice of card back, the object of the game being to dispose of all the cards in one's hand.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's user guide opens in a new window
Here an 8 has been played and the player is being asked to choose the new suit

title: Crazy Eights

description: Great Walls is a single-player Breakout-style game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. In this game the player has three balls, which they use one at a time, and the object the game is to break up the wall of blocks by bouncing the red ball off of them. The colour of the blocks changes towards the top of the game area, the higher the block the more points are scored when it is destroyed.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game plays in a small window

title: Great Walls

description: Hex Trap is a single-player, mouse controlled, Minesweeper style game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. This game is fairly typical of Minesweeper games in the way it plays. What makes it a bit different is that instead of playing on a grid of squares this implementation is played on a grid of hexagons. The game has a high score screen that holds the top six high scores.
title: Hex Trap

description: Juggler is a single-player, mouse controlled game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. The object of the game is to keep balls in play by moving a paddle left/right along the bottom of the screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file is accessed via the menu bar, it opens in a new window

title: Juggler

description: Labyrinth is a single-player, mouse controlled game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. The object of the game is to manoeuvre a marble around a maze by 'tilting' the game area. Once this has been achieved a new maze is created and the player continues until they run out of lives/balls.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file is accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window

A game in progress
The marble is navigated around the maze by using the mouse on the tilt control panel in the upper right

title: Labyrinth

description: Lock Out is a single-player, keyboard controlled game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. In this game the player manoeuvres their blue marble and attempts to capture territory while avoiding the red marbles inside the game area and the silver ball that patrols the border around it. The game has three levels of difficulty and the player must capture 75% of the game area in order to complete a level.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file opens in a new window
As the game progresses it becomes harder as the red balls are harder to avoid

title: Lock Out

description: Meteor Storm is a single-player, mouse controlled game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. This is a Missile Command-style game where the player has a single base with which they must protect their city from meteors and UFOs. They start the game with two hundred missiles and at the end of each level, assuming both the city and the player's base have survived, replacement missiles are provided.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file opens in a new window

title: Meteor Storm

description: Space Guard is a single-player, Asteroids-style game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. In this game the player has to protect the earth from approaching space rocks and aliens. The space ship can be controlled by both the mouse or the keyboard, has optional sound, and has three degrees of difficulty. The game ends when the player has no more ships or the earth is destroyed.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file opens in a new window, here it is showing the game's controls

title: Space Guard

description: Trails is a single-player, keyboard controlled, Light Cycle-style game. It was developed by the Cosmi Corporation and is featured in a number of their compilations. In it the player has to outwit an AI opponent and navigate their way around the screen while avoiding both their opponent's trail and their own.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file opens in a new window. It is accessed via the game's menu bar

title: Trails

description:
This compilation contains:

  • Black Rein
  • F-18: No Fly Zone
  • Quatra Command
title: Triple Threat: An Arcade Adventure

description: Black Rein is an arcade war game where the player drives a futuristic hover-tank, called T60 Black Rein. There are twenty missions to play where you are to destroy enemy tanks, escort friendly convoys and eventually destroy the enemy HQ. You view the world from within your tank while driving and shooting, there is an overhead map to help you navigate, and a short encyclopedia describing the seven types of enemy vehicles.

sample_screenshots.caption: I guess I failed to cool down the weapon system somehow.
Mission start; view from inside tank.

This is the same as our titular T60 hover tank.
(Ours is named differently, but looks almost the same)

An enemy tank, as shown in the encyclopedia.
Our gun is a bit hot I think.
Mission 1 briefing; in this menu we also have some settings for e.g. sound & difficulty.

title: Black Rein

description:
Egyptian Chopper Force is a single player, single screen, freeware shooter that was made with the Klik & Play game development tool.

In this game the mouse cursor becomes a helicopter. Bombs appear on the right and bounce around the screen, the player has five lives with which they shoot as many as possible.
The game has a midi sound track and shows the player's score at the end of a game however there is no high score table

sample_screenshots.caption: The game exits with this reminder
This is it folks, shoot those sputniks!

title: Egyptian Chopper Force

description:
Air Strike is a single player, mouse controlled shooter.

The shareware version of the game contains Episode One: Air Attack. This is a simple ten level game in which the mouse cursor becomes a targeting reticule for an anti aircraft gun. Enemy aircraft of various sizes appear, some fly towards the player towards the player, some fly across the screen at an angle, others fly away from the player off into the distance.
Using their mouse/gun and limited ammunition the player must shoot these planes down, each plane scores points with the smaller planes scoring more because they are harder to hit.
Later the action moves to the coast where the enemy are more cautions and harder to hit. Finally, just to make things even harder the player has to fend off attacks at night.

The registered version contains two further episodes. In Episode Two: The Pillbox the player controls a gun emplacement and must defend their position against tanks and/or storm troopers etc. In Episode Three: Sub Hunt the action moves out to sea with the player commanding a destroyer and fighting U-Boats

sample_screenshots.caption:
Episode 1: Air Strike
Game Over! This was supposed to be the easy section"

Episode 1: Air Strike
Out of ammunition. This does not look good

Episode 1: Air Strike
Here the come!
The title screen. Episode 1 was released as shareware
The high score table comes pre-populated

title: Air Strike

description: Dr. Wong's Jacks+ Video Poker for Windows published for Windows 3.0 or higher as Volume 22 of the popular Coffee Break Series, is a remake of the second volume of that series, Dr. Wong's Jacks+ Video Poker, which is in turn an abridged version of Stanford Wong's Video Poker that features only the "Jacks or better" variety. The player can choose to bet 1 to 5 coins, adjust the starting bankroll and the payoffs for various hands. The tutor could be asked to warn against an ill-advised play, or to select the cards to be held automatically, as well as to analyze the hand and its odds for winning.

sample_screenshots.caption: Payouts could be modified as well
Analysis window: a pair is common and not much profitable combination
A pair: 5 coins bet, 5 coins won

title: Dr. Wong's Jacks+ Video Poker for Windows

alternate_titles.title: Final Approach: Designer and Library of approach plates for Flight Simulators

description:
Final Approach is an add-on for Microsoft Flight Simulator versions 5 and 5.1. The purpose of this add-on is to provide the player/pilot with accurate approach plates to any airfield, over seventeen hundred that are supplied and the player can use this product to create their own.

The player starts by opening the flight simulator and lining up their aircraft for a landing, at this point they save their flight as a new Flight Simulator Situation file. Then in Final Approach they select the airfield of their choice , together with the position of their plane (latitude, longitude and altitude), the program then calculates the headings and descent rate the layer must follow to land the plane. These details are then saved, replacing the new situation file the player created in step one so that when the player next accesses that file from within the flight simulator they find themselves about to land at their designated airfield

Naturally there's more to Final Approach than just this, approach plans can be created, edited or deleted; new navigation points can be added; they can be printed, saved and shared. While data can be imported into Microsoft Flight Simulator the printed plans can also be used with subLOGIC's ATP and A320.

sample_screenshots.caption: A few navigation points have been edited in but one is incorrect and is being removed. Instead of 'Click+delete' the program numbers the items and uses a scroll bar to select it
Back in the simulator with the Final Approach situation loaded and our new location is exactly as specified, and for some reason it is now night time
In the flight simulator the player pauses their flight, here we're in a bit of a spin over the sea, and saves their current state as a new situation called SLOWDESC
Back in the flight simulator there are now two 'slow descent' files, one is the original saved situation while FINAPP is a renamed version of the Final Approach created situation
Starting off by selecting an airport. The player first selects the geographical area, (USA, Europe or Other) and then searches for the airport they want

title: Final Approach

description:
Earth Invasion is a collection of three shoot 'em up games presented as missions accessible from a command central.* Earth Orbit Mission is a traditional fixed screen shoot 'em up where the player moves a craft around the bottom half of the screen and shoots at the enemies appearing from the top. The objective of the mission is to reduce the number of enemy crafts that are moving towards the player's planet.

  • Ground Mission is played from a side view and resembles Defender with the player being able to turn around and fly both to the left and to the right. The task here is to defend the citizens on the planet's surface while defeating the remaining enemies.

  • Deep Space Mission is played from a first person perspective. The enemies are in retreat and the player has to follow them and finish them once and for all. The gameplay is limited to moving a cross hair across the screen and shoot the enemy ships as they appear.

In all games the space ship is equipped with a phasor for basic firepower and a photon cannon that takes out numerous enemies in a single blast. There are also various special weapons (guiding, spreaders, accelerators) which are made available through power ups (auxiliary munitions). Other power ups give additional shield, ammo or points bonuses.
title: Earth Invasion

description:
Boulderland is a Boulder Dash clone. It supports keyboard and joystick controls. There is an in-built editor, and a "replay" feature. Twenty standard levels are included, but there is support for up to 999.

The main gameplay involves collecting a certain number of giant red gems and then, when the right number has been collected, heading to the exit to complete the level and move on to the next one, all within the time limit. You use the cursor keys or the joystick to move, but if you move while holding down the left shift key (or the joystick button), you can affect the tile in that direction actually moving into that position. The main complication is boulders: when each level starts the boulders are supported by the ground underneath them, but as you dig through the level to get to the gems, eventually you will need to dig directly underneath a boulder, leaving an empty space underneath it. Since it is no longer supported by anything, it will start to fall. If a falling boulder lands on you, you lose a life. You can push a boulder left or right, but only if there is an empty space on the other side, and only if it is not currently falling.

Then there are other game mechanics familiar to those who have played other versions and variants of Boulder Dash: monsters that move around inside empty space, and explode if you touch them, or a boulder falls on them; a self-replicating amoeba that expands until it is completely trapped, then transforms into gems; a type of magical wall that transforms falling boulders into gems, if there is empty space underneath it; a wall with a gap that closes up as you dig through it; and so on.

Boulderland also adds some new mechanics of its own, such as bubbles that you can burst (using numeric keys 4/8/6/2 for left/up/right/down) and bombs that you can collect then deploy (also using the numeric keys).
title: Boulderland

description:
Patuman is a shareware Pac-Man clone with a vaguely nightmarish aesthetic. It is controlled with the keyboard, using space to start the game and the cursor keys to move around.

You play the role of Patuman, a yellow-green face wearing sunglasses in a labyrinth full of small yellow pellets. In the center of the labyrinth is a zone where several monsters live. You cannot enter the monster zone, but the monsters can leave it, and chase you around the labyrinth. If they catch you, you will lose a life. If you lose all your lives, the game is over. As well as the smaller yellow pellets, there are a few big pellets that allow you to temporarily eat the monsters. The monsters are normally a color, like blue or cyan, but while you can eat them they all change to white. When you collect all the pellets in the labyrinth, you start a new level.

The game attempts to automatically detect the best speed to run at as it starts up. You can also adjust the speed using menu items in the application menu.
title: Patuman

alternate_titles.title: Scholastic's El Autobús Mágico Explora el Sistema Solar
Scholastic: Allacciate le cinture! - Esploriamo il Sistema Solare

description: The Magic School Bus Explores the Solar System is the first title of Microsoft’s Magic School Bus educational game series. Ms. Frizzle is lost somewhere in outer space and as the player gathers clues from every planet he/she visits, they will also learn about the nine planets of the solar system with fun facts. Ten mini-games and nine experiments are included, as well as video clips from NASA. The recommended age group is 6 to 10.

sample_screenshots.caption: The intro movie has a smaller resolution than the rest of the game
Each planet has a science experiment, here a comparison between Earth and Mercury days
On the planet view we can trigger animations, too

title: Scholastic's The Magic School Bus Explores the Solar System

description:
Animation Hangman is a variant of the word guessing pen and paper game where short video clips of 3D animations act as clues. Other than that it works like any other Hangman game with the player being presented with a hidden word that have to be guessed by entering letters one at a time. Correct guesses lead to the letters being filled in while incorrect guesses lead to a stick figure being drawn. After six wrong guesses the man is hanged.

In addition to the standard Hangman game, there is an additional game mode called Multiple Puzzle Hangman. It works the same but the player automatically moves on to a new puzzle when one is completed. The hangman is not erased between puzzles so all the wrong guesses gets carried over. The aim is to get a high score by completing as many puzzles as possible.
title: Animation Hangman

description:
This is an enhanced version of the original Microsoft Golf that takes advantage of the CD-ROM format. It adds video tutorials, video previews of each hole, and video tips supplied by both male and female actors.

As with the original game, up to eight players can compete on the included 18-hole golf course of Torrey Pines, located in San Diego, California.
title: Microsoft Golf: Multimedia Edition

description:
The Junior Science Series is a collection of educational computer games on the topic of science for ages 4 to 8. This is the second volume focusing on shadows. The player can select a page to go to in the main navigation screen. Once a page has been selected, the player can choose a story or game to play from. The Wiseman stories allows the player to choose a picture and listen to some fun facts about science and nature.

The fun and games allow the player to click around the screen for hidden surprises and help the cartoon characters solve problems with different difficulty level settings. After a section is complete, the buttons highlight to choose with section to go to next. The main navigation screen can still be accessed by clicking on the door icon at the bottom left of each page. The player can also click on the scroll with the question mark to listen to narrated instructions in most of the sections of the game.
title: The Junior Science Series Volume 2: Shadows

description:
The Junior Science Series is a collection of educational computer games on the topic of science for ages 4 to 8. This is the third volume focusing on directions. The player can select a page to go to in the main navigation screen. Once a page has been selected, the player can choose a story or game to play from. The Wiseman stories allows the player to choose a picture and listen to some fun facts about science and nature.

The fun and games allow the player to click around the screen for hidden surprises and help the cartoon characters solve problems with different difficulty level settings. After a section is complete, the buttons highlight to choose with section to go to next. The main navigation screen can still be accessed by clicking on the door icon at the bottom left of each page. The player can also click on the scroll with the question mark to listen to narrated instructions in most of the sections of the game.
title: The Junior Science Series Volume 3: Directions

description:
The Junior Science Series is a collection of educational computer games on the topic of science for ages 4 to 8. This is the fourth volume focusing on distance. The player can select a page to go to in the main navigation screen. Once a page has been selected, the player can choose a story or game to play from. The Wiseman stories allows the player to choose a picture and listen to some fun facts about science and nature.

The fun and games allow the player to click around the screen for hidden surprises and help the cartoon characters solve problems with different difficulty level settings. After a section is complete, the buttons highlight to choose with section to go to next. The main navigation screen can still be accessed by clicking on the door icon at the bottom left of each page. The player can also click on the scroll with the question mark to listen to narrated instructions in most of the sections of the game.
title: The Junior Science Series Volume 4: Distance

description:
The Junior Science Series is a collection of educational computer games on the topic of science for ages 4 to 8. This is the fifth volume focusing on light. The player can select a page to go to in the main navigation screen. Once a page has been selected, the player can choose a story or game to play from. The Wiseman stories allows the player to choose a picture and listen to some fun facts about science and nature.

The fun and games allow the player to click around the screen for hidden surprises and help the cartoon characters solve problems with different difficulty level settings. After a section is complete, the buttons highlight to choose with section to go to next. The main navigation screen can still be accessed by clicking on the door icon at the bottom left of each page. The player can also click on the scroll with the question mark to listen to narrated instructions in most of the sections of the game.
title: The Junior Science Series Volume 5: Light

description:
Combo Pack is the name used by Double Oak Software when they sold both their Arcade Pack and Parlor Pack as a single product.

These games were sold on-line, downloaded and later registered
title: Combo Pack

description:
Shogi Variants is a single player, freeware game which contains seventeen variations of the game Shogi which is a form of Japanese Chess. The games are grouped into the three categories shown below, the numbers in brackets indicate the size of the board;* Modern Games: Shogi (9x9), Micro Shogi (4x5), Mini Shogi (5x5), Judjin'd Shogi (6x6), Whale Shogi (6x6), Yari Shogi (7x9)

  • Later Games 1200-1800 AD: Tori Shogi (7x7), Sho Shogi (9x9), Wa Shogi (11x11), Chu shogi (12x12), Dai shogi (15x15), Tenjiku Shogi (16x16), Dai-Dai Shogi (17x17), Maka-Dai-Dai Shogi (19x19), Tai Shogi (25x25)
  • Early Games 800-1200 AD: heian Shogi (9x8), Heian Dai Shogi (13x13)
