title: Draw 5: Draw Poker for Windows

description:
PentoPuzzle is an implementation of a mathematical tiling puzzle that evolved during the 1950’s and 60’s and has since been released as a child’s toy. The object of the game is played on one of four grids 6x10; 5x12; 4x15; and 3x20 with twelve pentomino tiles (that is a shape made up of five equal sized squares similar to the four square shapes in Tetris).

This game is played with the mouse, a piece can be rotated 90° with a left mouse click or flipped to their mirror image with a double click.

This game was released as postcardware, i.e. all the author asked is that if anyone liked the game could they send him a postcard so he'd know his work was not in vain.

sample_screenshots.caption: The start of a game with the drop down menu showing the alternate grid sizes

title: PentoPuzzle

description:
Pirate's Gold is a freeware solitaire card game, it is mouse controlled and plays in a fixed size window.

In this game the full deck of fifty-two cards is used. It starts by dealing two rows of five cards face up on the table, these are the ‘Pirate’s Gold Pieces’. Once the initial cards have been dealt the player uses the mouse to click on pairs of cards with the same number, these are removed and replaced by two cards from the deck. The object of the game is to pair off all the cards until the deck is exhausted.

sample_screenshots.caption:
Game over!
This may be a little picky but shouldn't that say 'You Have Won'?
The menu bar doesn't hold a great deal. The only option is to open the help file of which there are two windows of this size

title: Pirate's Gold

description:
Puzzle Pack is a single-player, shareware collection of jigsaw-like puzzles, there are two puzzles in the shareware game and five puzzles in the registered game.

Unlike a traditional jigsaw where the player is reassembling a picture and can use the original picture as a reference and/or their own experience to place larger objects in the foreground, sky at the top etc these puzzles are simply about putting the pieces together so that the colours at the junctions match and the whole assembly fits into a specified grid.

The puzzles are:* Puzzle 1: this is a Square Puzzle, nine square pieces with one color on each side which fit together into a 3x3 square.

  • Puzzle 2: a harder variation of puzzle one but now each piece has a knob sticking in or out of each side. The above puzzles are present in the shareware and registered version, the following puzzles are only present in the registered version

  • Puzzle 3: here seven hexagons must be arranged to form a larger hexagon.

  • Puzzle 4: in this puzzle sixteen triangles are used to make a larger triangular puzzle.

  • Puzzle 5: twenty-five squares each with two different colours form a 5x5 square.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is the start of puzzle two
The game's help file can be accessed via the menu bar
The game starts with a shareware reminder

title: Puzzle Pack

description:
Rummy 500 is a shareware implementation of the game that is sometimes referred to as Five Hundred Rum. The real-life game is for two players, here it is played against the machine.

The basic game is a variant of rummy where players meld cards of the same rank or in sequence by suit. Points are scored for cards laid on the table while cards that remain in the player’s hands at the end of a round count against them. The game gets its name because the winner is the first to five hundred points.

This game plays the standard game as defined by Hoyle’s rules, however there are multiple variations available in the menu bar along with other features such as autoplay, statistics and league tables, six levels of AI opponent, and save/load functions.

The shareware version has a nag screen that appears between rounds and pauses the game for five seconds.

This too is displayed the first time the game is player

Shareware Version 4.2

title: Rummy 500

description:
Safebuster is a single-player, shareware game in which the player has to find the hidden combination to open a safe. The first level has three reels with the numbers 0-10, 0-5, 0-5 on each giving three hundred and ninety-six possible combinations, but bigger numbers are used as the player progresses. The player uses sliders next to each reel to adjust the number showing. All the levels are timed and the time allotted for this level is twenty seconds. When a safe has been opened the player receives a password so that they can restart the puzzle at the next level.

The shareware version has just eight levels while the registered version has twenty, plus at the end of each level there is a bonus round.

sample_screenshots.caption:
At the start of each stage the player is given the time allowed to solve the puzzle

Shareware version

The start of a game

Shareware version

The help file opens in a new window

Shareware version

title: Safebuster

description:
Shift Zone is a single-player, mouse controlled puzzle game.

In this game the player is presented with a series of levels, each level consisting of twelve puzzles which must all be solved before the player can progress. All puzzles are of the same type and require a logical approach. Each puzzle consists of a series of touching coloured rectangles, each rectangle has a number, from one to six, associated with it and that determines the colour. Clicking on any shape reduces it’s numbered state, and the state of all touching shapes, by one until eventually it becomes a ‘Shift Zone’.

The object of the game is to change the state of every rectangle into a ‘Shift Zone’ but there’s a catch, ‘Shift Zones’ are unstable and will explode and end the game if changed so:* Once a rectangle has achieves ‘Shift Zone’ status it cannot be clicked on again or the puzzle is over and the player has to start again.

  • Clicking on a shape connected to a ‘Shift Zone’ would result in an attempt to reduce the state of the ‘Shift Zone’ by one which would cause it to explode and the player has to start again.

Once a puzzle is solved the player cannot play it again, when all twelve puzzles in a level have been solved the player progresses to the next level. The game has Save/Load functions and a high score table, it is played with the mouse and runs in two windows - the main window which can be moved/dragged around the screen and a small daughter window that shows the colour sequence which cannot.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game Over - but at least there's a high score

the game starts with a 'Game Over' screen
The main window can be moved about, the smaller 'Progression' window cannot

title: Shift Zone

description:
Sir Hangman is a single player, shareware, mouse controlled implementation of the standard Hangman game that was sold as an educational tool.

This game differs from others as the hanging man is a cowboy, clued to the words are offered, and instead of typing letters via the keyboard the player uses the mouse to select letters from an on-screen keyboard which can be re-ordered and repositioned.

In the shareware version there were four groups Animals (Easy), General Science and Social Studies (both Medium), and Puns (Hard) while the registered version had twelve groups and over a thousand words and phrases.

sample_screenshots.caption: Category selection, shareware version. The registered version has twelve groupings
The shape of the on-screen keyboard can be changed and it can be relocated
There is a help file. It can be opened separately of from within the game
The game starts by selecting or creating a player id

title: Sir Hangman

description:
WinBridge is a single-player implementation of the standard game, the player and their AI partner play North-South and take on an AI pair playing East-West in either rubber or duplicate bridge. The game opens in a window but can be played in full screen mode, it is entirely mouse controlled.

The bridge bidding system is based on ACOL and the supports following conventions; weak, strong or variable no trump; Standard or Benjamin opening two bids; Stayman and/or Blackwood two club responses; Blackwood or Gerber when slam seeking; and take-out doubles. It also allows the North-South pair to play different conventions to the East-West pair. One of the configuration options can be used to bias the contracts towards either pair which is useful when practising attacking and defensive play

There’s a useful help file which explains the controls, the basics of bridge and the ACOL bidding system. The shareware version of the game is fully functional other than it does not allow the player top save any configuration changes, while the registered version has additional features such as being able to replay a trick, set up specific hands to play and being able to pause the autoplay feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting a new game. It's important to check the conventions being used
The completion of the auction, five clubs doubled
There is a comprehensive help file which explains the game for those who are using the game as a tutor
When a hand has been completed it can be reviewed

title: WinBridge

description:
Word Wrestle is a single-player, shareware, word game in which the player has to construct words from random letters on a grid. The grid size can vary a little, it can be 4x4, 4x5, 5x4 or 5x5 and in the standard game the letters are selected randomly, the only rule being that each letter in a word must be horizontally, vertically or diagonally adjacent to the next letter. The game plays in a window by default but can also be played in full screen mode, the mouse is used for the game controls but words are entered via the keyboard..

The game comes with options to use American or British spelling, different fonts plus the tools to update the dictionary and to create and save puzzles.

sample_screenshots.caption: The first time the game is played the player is asked for their country. This presumably is used to determine which word spellings are allowed
The end of a game. These are the words the player found. Note that there are lots of words that were not found because, though the letters are present they were not connected
A standard, random, game in progress
The player can add words to the dictionary

Creating a custom puzzle
This shows the game playing in full screen mode but it can play in a window too

title: Word Wrestle

description:
Adventure Gamer for Windows is a shareware authoring program that aided the development of text adventure games, it was also used to play games and contained two example games:

  • The Training Game: This is described as ‘not really a game’, and it’s more an example of how a game is put together, players are advised to complete this before attempting the full game.
  • The Gates of Macrohard: This is a ‘full sized’, playable text adventure that is a play on IBM/Microsoft. The player has to save the world from domination by JCN Macrohard of the 3.11th dimension.

The shareware package allowed the creation of small games, thus the ‘Training Game’ can be edited, while The Gates of Macrohard could be played but could not be edited as it was too large for the unregistered software.

sample_screenshots.caption: The description for the full game 'The gates of Macrohard' also opens in a separate window
The description of 'The Training Game' opens in a separate window. Though it's described as being 'not really a game' it's effectively a training level for the full game
The game authoring function showing the way the 'Training Game' is put together. This can be edited and games of this size can be created

title: Adventure Gamer for Windows

description:
Win Battle is a single-player, shareware Star Trek -style game.

The story behind this game is that the Rollons have attacked and destroyed all of Earth’s colonies. As commander of the last remaining battlestar you have been tasked with finding all survivors and guiding them to safety as well as destroying all Rollon ships.

The game is played in a grid universe where the player warps from one sector to another locating ships, enemies, planets etc however the player cannot warp to any cell in the grid, only those which are adjacent to the current location. The ship has missiles, lasers and fighters as well as shields etc, all of these can be damaged in combat in which case the player must find a safe cell to rest and repair vital systems.

The game is presented as one main window within which are a series of child windows showing ship status, plus strategic and tactical maps. It is played by a combination of mouse and keyboard controls. There are three levels of difficulty, optional sound effects, and a high score table. The game can be played in a window or in full screen mode.

sample_screenshots.caption: Right clicking in the Tactical screen brings up this menu. The options can be triggered with either the mouse or the keyboard
The game starts with the player's ship making a grand entrance
This is the visual effect when warping from one sector to another
The shareware game starts up with an explanation of the various parts of the screen. There is a full description of all the controls in the game's help file
The game has a detailed help file. This can be accessed via the menu bar

title: Win Battle

description:
The Inside World is a single-player, shareware, role-playing game. The shareware version of the game has three levels while the registered 'Professional' version has ten.

The story behind the game is based on five college students. Their professor is a typical eccentric genius who experiments with insects and radiation in his spare time. What the students didn't know is that the prof's family have been performing experiments for ages in their castle which just happens to be under their dorm. One day one of the students comes across an entrance to the underworld so he and his four companions decide to investigate. The objectives of the game are to explore the dungeons, kill all the bad things therein, discover treasure and escape.

This is a top-down game with all the action taking place in a small window in the top central half of the screen. Though the player has five characters they do not work as a team, if one character dies another takes their place, usually in the same place but without the weapons, armour or equipment. The dungeons are, naturally, mazelike in their construction with plenty of locked doors, and items to pick up. The character's inventory system is split with general items going into a backpack, and separate items for keys, ammunition etc while weapons and protective clothing are added to the character directly.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is a shareware game and the unregistered version opens with an invitation to order the full game
The game starts above ground where the unarmed player is heavily outmatched by the monsters. better get below ground quickly
Safe, well safe for now, below ground. The writing on the wall is a hint because there are clues and bits of useful information scratched into the walls
Some items are hidden in holes in the wall, this is a corncob - another source of food

the last action was to read a note from the developer
Just found a fish which has got to be a sort of health boost hasn't it? Of course it could be a red herring

title: The Inside World

description:
Win Pelvis-N-Space is a single player, shareware Star Trek-style game very much like BFM’s game Win Battle.

In this game aliens are once again the source of much trouble. Here the aliens live around thirty or so light years away so they’ve only recently received our transmissions of Pelvis and his music. Pelvismania has started on their world just as it did on ours but, while we had the real thing they have nothing so they jumped in their battlecruisers and headed to Earth to kidnap Pelvis and steal Pelvis’ relics. They came in three types of ship, the Hound Dog class, the Heartbreak Hotel class and the Rock-n-Roll class and they stole a Gold Album, Fender Guitar, White Studded Jumpsuit, Peanut-butter & Bananas, Pink Cadillac, 8-track tape, and a Black Velvet Painting.

The object of the game is to destroy the enemy ships and retrieve the artifacts and Pelvis. It is played in a grid universe where the player warps from one sector to another locating enemy ships, planets e.t.c. however the player cannot warp to any cell in the grid, only those which are adjacent to the current location. The ship has missiles, attack drones and decoy ships as well as shields e.t.c, all of these can be damaged in combat in which case the player must find a safe cell to rest and repair vital systems. There are three levels of difficulty Beginner where the enemies fire slower and the player has fewer weapons, Normal and Advanced where the player has more weapons but there are far more enemies in the galaxy.

The game is presented as one main window within which are a series of child windows showing ship status, together with strategic and tactical maps. It is played by a combination of mouse and keyboard controls and can be played in both window or full screen mode.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game has a detailed help file that can be accessed in-game. It open in a new window
The game scrolls the background story in this small daughter window
Here we've warped into a sector containing a Hound Dog class ship
The in-game help option explains all the controls

title: Win Pelvis-N-Space

description:
Quenzar's Caverns is a shareware, single-player dungeon crawl type of game.

The story behind the game is simple enough, the player is a mighty hero/heroine who has decided to rid the realm of Quenzar an evil wizard who is plotting to take over the kingdom. The game has two skill settings and, according to the accompanying description, an experienced player should complete it in under an hour. There is no save game function.

The game area is split into four parts. In the upper left is a game map which consists of a 10x10 grid where each cell is a room. In the centre is a compass rose which the player uses to navigate the map and above this are two picture slots which show the current room’s contents. On the left are the characters statistics, strength, amount of gold found etc and below that are buttons for attack, defend, flee and so on. Underneath all of this is are two text boxes one describes the current room, the other lists the actions taken and their results so any messages are received here and in battle the results of each strike are shown here.

The game plays in a window or in full screen mode and has randomly generated environments so each game should be different. The game environments are numbered and the player has the option of playing a random game or a specific numbered game, number 8655 is used as the tutorial game and is described in a walkthrough which, if played perfectly, can be completed in twenty moves. The object of the game is to find Queznar and kill him/her. However before the player can enter the lair they must search the rest of the rooms for the key and additional equipment, that means fighting monsters and avoiding traps and not wasting any weapons so they are fully armed when they enter Queznar's lair.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game starts by showing the game area overlaid with a title screen, the title screen is replaced by this shareware reminder screen which forces the player to wait for several seconds
The start of a game. The game starts off with a new random game each time, here the player is entering a specific game number to follow the tutorial
There's a grey 'Statistics & Inventory' button in the mid-right of the game screen, this is what it does
The game starts by showing the game area overlaid with a title screen.
The game comes with a comprehensive help file. This can be accessed via the menu bar

title: Quenzar's Caverns

description:
SuperHer is a single player, shareware, mouse controlled RPG-like game.

The game starts in a small farming community in Vermont, USA. Your mother has died, dad is sick and your sister, Angela, is missing which leaves you on your own to run the family farm. Looking through your dad’s old things for clues to your sister’s whereabouts you discover that years ago your parents were superheroes, dad used to be SuperHim and your mum was Mistress Thumper. Donning your dad’s power ring you set off to find Angela.

After the optional introduction the player sets the character’s strength, health and agility before assigning extra points on things like heat vision, lightning and body armour. The game starts in the city where you have taken an apartment which is the game’s first location. Each location comes with a series of options many of which are humorous, for example in our apartment one of the options is to make a sandwich so naturally you make a hero sandwich, other options include putting more clothes on – SuperHer is only wearing a bikini, or taking everything off.

Outside the apartment the player is shown a map of the city with key locations on it. Some locations lead directly to confrontation and battle while others provide information on Angela or equipment. All battles are shown on a screen with the player on the left and their opponent on the left. The player uses the mouse to decide what action to take, punch, heat vision, lightning etc and the game implements that choice returning a message something like ‘You Smack your opponent for <2> points’, they then smack you and so it goes until the player either wins, quits or dies. Petty thugs are encountered first and some can be easily vanquished while the major villains are much tougher.

sample_screenshots.caption: The cat burglar is only visible with night vision goggles
A scene from the optional introduction
Not all locations lead to confrontation

title: SuperHer

description:
Win Trek is a single player, shareware Star Trek game.

As with most Star Trek games the player commands a starship and must defeat the dastardly aliens, (here called Romights, Klinions, Fergans, and Borbans) who oppose the United Planets.

The game is played in a grid universe where the player warps from one sector to another locating ships, enemies, planets etc however the player cannot warp to any cell in the grid, only those which are close to the current location. The ship has photon torpedoes and phasers and shields etc, all of these can be damaged in combat in which case the player must find a safe cell to rest and repair vital systems. There are three skill levels and in the registered version the player can edit the level to change the number of opponents and well as the quantity of weapons their ship carries and how quickly systems are repaired.

The game is presented as one main window within which are a series of child windows showing ship status, plus strategic and tactical maps. It is played by a combination of mouse and keyboard controls.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the registered version the player can edit the game's parameters
The shareware game is time limited and starts with a reminder to register and pay
Once the story is out of the way the main game area is displayed together with explanations of the controls.
The game starts by displaying the storyline in a small window

title: Win Trek

description:
Bago is a single player, freeware, word game based on the board game Boggle, in this implementation the player plays against the computer..

The player is dealt twenty-five letters in a 5x5 grid and must construct as many words as possible, the only rules are that words must be at least four letters long; that each letter must be adjacent to the previous letter; and an individual letter can only be used once in a word.

The game can be played either by the keyboard or the mouse, the documentation warns against using a combination of the two when entering words as this causes a fault. The player can make the game harder by rotating the letters randomly and/or by adjusting the strength of the AI player.

The default game lasts for three minutes but this can be altered, the dictionary can be edited and the game can be instructed to learn words as they are used in play.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here the game has just ended, the player won, and the player is changing the default length of the game
Here  game is about to start and the player has accessed the 'quick guide' via the menu bqr
One way to make the game harder is to randomly rotate the pieces
A game in progress. The player forms the word then clicks on the big grey arrow button to enter that word and prepare for the next
In addition to the 'quick guide' there is a detailed help file which can also be accessed via the menu bar

title: Bago

description:
Block-Heads is a shareware implementation of Othello or Reversi.

This implementation is mouse controlled and has three levels of difficulty but what makes it that little bit different is that instead of the traditional counters the registered game can be configured to use the player’s face, or any other .bmp image. If the purchaser included a photograph with their registration request the developers would scan it into the game they returned for free.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game area prior to the start of a game
A game in progress. During the computer's turn the text that is displayed, in this case 'Checking available moves...' is accompanied by the same words spoken

title: Block-Heads

description:
Boxes is a single player, keyboard controlled, shareware falling block puzzle.

The story behind the game is that the player has been left alone on a space station and has been left alone to stack the colour coded boxes. All the boxes come in pairs are the same shape and size. The playing screen starts with some fixed boxes scattered around and it is the player’s job to stack four blocks of the same colour together at which point they are removed from the screen, the level ends when all the boxes present at the beginning are removed.

The shareware game is called Boxes and contains ten levels and the in-game music is a full midi rendition of Beethoven's Bagatelle No. 25 in A, more usually known as "Für Elise". The registered game is called Boxes: Championship Edition it has one hundred and fifty levels, more music tracks, more backgrounds and special boxes such as bombs and antigravity crates.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is displayed in the centre of the screen while the game loads
The shareware game has ten levels, the full game has one hundred and fifty
The start of level one. The object is to remove these crates by stacking more of the same colour on top
The levels become harder as the player progresses, there are now twelve crates to dispose of whereas level one had just four
The main screen with the story age from the game's help file showing

title: Boxes

description: Floppy Killer is an arcade game where the player controls a computer. The main goal is to shoot missiles and defend the spies located at the bottom of the screen against the bombs of system icons moving in horizontal directions above. The computer can only move left / right and shoot. Each kill of the icon or the bomb gives points, but each shot takes points. The game overs, when all five lives of the computer are left or all spies are dead. Highest scores are stored in top ten table.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title Screen with Main Menu (in Russian)

title: Floppy Killer

description: Escape (Побег) is an arcade game about a prisoner trying to escape the prison. The player controls this prisoner, who can move left and right, climb ladders, and jump over the gaps or lethal obstacles such as rolling bombs or flying bullets. From level to level on its way from a bottom of the screen to its top, the prisoner can collect various useful items such as additional live, bomb eliminator, bomb stopper, and others collected for the score. Game overs, when all prisoner's lives are left. Highest scores are stored in top ten table.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title Screen and Main Menu (in Russian)

title: Escape

description: Inspired by Color Lines, Honey Lines adds a certain specifics to the puzzle. As in the original game, the player's task is to assemble the rows of five or more same objects, but now the grid represents a hexagonal honeycomb, and the player can select the mode of the turn, i.e. either to move an item to a place or to swap two items in places. Game overs, when there are no more moves left for the player. Highest scores are stored in top ten table.
title: Honey Lines

description: U-95 is an arcade platformer about a submarine roaming the underwater caves full of treasures and deadly creatures. The player controls the submarine, searching the way out the tunnels, avoiding the contact with ground borders, shooting at the creatures, and collecting treasures and power-ups, which either raise the oxygen level or give additional abilities. Game overs, when all submarine lives are exhausted. Highest scores are stored in top ten table.

sample_screenshots.caption: Submarine's shape can be collected (in Russian)
Title Screen and Main Menu (in Russian)
It seems that the bottom way leads to the dead end (in Russian)

title: U-95

description:
Cell War is a shareware strategy game that can be played against either the computer of another human player. The game is based on rules similar to those laid down for John Horton Conway’s of Game of Life. It is a turn based game, when each player has completed their turn the game board is updated. When both players pass the game is over and the score is calculated with the winner being the player with the highest average number of cells throughout the game. In this game the rules are:* Any cell not touching another cell horizontally, vertically, or diagonally will die of loneliness.

  • Any cell touching four friendly cells horizontally or vertically will be suffocated.

  • Any cell touching three unfriendly cells horizontally or vertically will die from poisoning.

  • A new cell will be created when the square is surrounded by two or three friendly cells horizontally or vertically.

  • If, when the game board is updated a new cell may be created by either player in the same square the player who moved first in the will take the square.

There game configuration options include two levels of AI difficulty, the game board can be varied from 4x4 to 25x20, the number of cells populating the board at the start of the game can be altered as can the number of cells placed in each turn.

sample_screenshots.caption: The player downloaded the full game for evaluation. Registration bought a code which prevented the shareware nag screen from appearing
The start of a player v player game using the default settings
The game starts with a shareware nag screen
This game is nearly over. Green has most of the board and the purple position is both stable and unassailable

title: Cell War

description:
ColorBlind is a single player, freeware, colour matching game.

This is a simple but challenging game in which the player is presented with a square the left hand half of which is coloured while the right hand part is black. By moving slider bars the player adjusts the quantities of red, green and blue on the right half the player attempting to match the colour on the left.

The game allows the player to play with either limited or unlimited guesses, each guess totals the colour values and returns a hint ‘You are xx away from the correct answer’. They can also configure the game to use one, two or all three colours to make the match easier or harder. When the player correctly matches the colour there's no fanfare, no 'Well Done' message, the game immediately presents another colour.

sample_screenshots.caption: The title screen. This is displayed over the game area
The start of a game. The default setting appears to be a three colour game with unlimited guesses

Not quite there but we're close.
The hint given here is optional and can be disabled via a menu bar comfiguration control

title: ColorBlind

description:
The Egg Carton Game is a two-player strategy game that can either be played against another player or an AI opponent which has three difficulty settings.

The game itself similar to Mancala, that game traditionally uses seeds or stones in pits while this game uses marbles in the wells of an egg carton, but the object is the same in as each player tries to clear all the marbles from their side of the game area. The game area is similar too with each side having six slots and right and left ‘end slots that marbles can be played into but cannot be played out of.

Each player in turn selects a slot and the marbles in it are removed and distributed around the board in an anticlockwise direction, for example if slot ‘x’ contained three marbles then it would be emptied and one marble would be placed in cell ‘x+1’, the second in cell ‘x+2’ and the third in cell ‘x+3’. Choosing the right cell is important because the strategy element depends upon the last cell into which a marble is played:* If the last marble drops off the board the player must choose a cell on their side of the board from which to make another move.

  • If the last marble goes into a cell that has one or more marbles in it, all the marbles from that cell (including the one just dropped there) are removed and distributed counter-clockwise from that point.

  • If the last cell into which a marble is dropped was EMPTY the player's turn is over and the opponent's turn begins.

The game plays in a non-resizeable window and has neither a save game facility or any game statistics.

sample_screenshots.caption: here the player's move ended with the last marble landing in the right hand end slot so they get another go
This is either a brilliant winning position or the AI opponent is about to trash me

title: The Egg Carton Game

description:
Electro-Cute is a single player word guessing game based on the classic Hangman format, however here, instead of being hung the unfortunate prisoner is electrocuted once they are assembled.

The game has sound effects, three levels of difficulty and the registered version allows users to add words to the dictionary (the shareware game comes with just a fifteen word library). It plays in a non-resizeable window and accepts input via mouse or keyboard.

sample_screenshots.caption: After an incorrect guess the player is shown the word

A game in progress
The player selects letters either with the mouse or the keybard

This time the word was not guessed
Are the feet on backwards?
There is a help file. It is accessed via the menu bar and opens in a new window
This time the word was guessed correctly

title: Electro-Cute

description:
Fruits Fields is a single-player, shareware, Soko-Ban type of puzzle game from Hong-Kong.

The shareware game has fifty levels, the full game has one hundred levels. In each level the object is to guide Nic around the game area and collect fruit. In the way are crates which will only move in the direction of the arrow they carry. Some crates can be destroyed by pushing them into a wall or, in certain circumstances, another crate. Points are scored for each piece of fruit collected and for each crate destroyed but one point is deducted for each square moved. The level is complete when the last piece of fruit has been collected, not when all crates have been destroyed. For each level completed the player exposes a segment of a pretty picture.

The game has a high score table, music, sound effects and can be played by the mouse or the keyboard in a window or full-screen

sample_screenshots.caption:
The high score table. When Moby Gamer logs back in to play again the game remembers the level they were playing and restarts from that point

Version 2.01

title: Fruits Fields

description:
Fire Away! is a two-player, freeware, keyboard controlled game. In this game the players’ characters face each other as in a duel and blast away with their weapons alternately ducking in and out of a hiding position, while hiding a player cannot be hit but neither can they fire. Eventually one or other player dies, the kill count is increased, the player is resurrected and the game continues.

The game was created using Klik & Play and has three scenarios:* Gangsta Wars: The two players have standard pistols and it takes multiple hits to kill either of them, the shots are not that accurate

  • Heavy Firepower: One player uses a bazooka which is accurate, the other some kind of laser which is not accurate. One hit is all it takes to kill.

  • Reality Sucks: The player on the right has a pistol and must hit their opponent ten times to score a kill, the player on the left has a ray gun and can kill with one shot

This game was included on a compilation CD and was one of the few programs that had to be installed before it would run. It plays in either a window or full screen, there is no high score table and no single player option.

sample_screenshots.caption: Reality Sucks: The guy on the right has a pistol and must hit the other guy twenty times to score a kill. The guy on the left has a 'one hit, one kill' ray gun
Heavy Firepower. The bazooka always hits its target. The laser is not so accurate - there's a bolt above and to the right of the green man's head
The game's help information is a short file in .wri format that has the company name and details of the controls

title: Fire Away!

description:
Gold Monkey is a single player, mouse controlled strategy game that is something of a cross between Minesweeper and Snake.

The game is played in a window containing a 25x20 grid. In most of the cells there is a number, a couple of the cells contain a red spider and one cell contains a banana – this is the starting point.

Beneath each numbered cell is a banana and the object of the game is to reveal every banana on the game board. Starting with the single revealed banana the player clicks on any of the adjacent cells horizontally, vertically or diagonally. The game uses the number and position of that cell to reveal a row of bananas, so if the player clicked on the cell to the right of the start banana and it contained a number five then the game would reveal five bananas in a row to the right and the start point for the next move would be at the end of the line.

The game ends if the player either touches one of the red spiders, goes off the edge of the game area or attempts to re-use an exposed cell. The game records the top five scores, a player's score being the percentage of the bananas cleared in a game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game records the top five scores
The similarity with Snake games continues, in Snake you cannot cross your own tail and here you cannot use the same cell twice

Game Over!
The first move was my last, moving seven cells in a diagonal direction when there just wasn't enough room on the board
The game area and the game instructions
A game is underway. The trail is reminiscent of the game Snake

title: Gold Monkey

description:
Gopher-It is a single player, shareware, mouse controlled Whac-A-Mole game in which players hit gophers over the head with a padded club to stop them overrunning the place. In addition to the gophers there are rabbits which also score points, skunks which incur penalty points, bombs which end the game and dynamite which removes one gopher hole.

The player must achieve a fifty percent hit rate on each level in order to continue. The game has sound, three speed settings and maintains a record of the top score.
title: Gopher-It

description:
Jeu d'Henri is a single player, freeware, mouse controlled game.

The game is based on the Japanese game Nim. In this version the player is presented with columns of coins, column one has three coins, column two has five and column three has seven.

The player plays against the computer and in their turn a player can remove any number of coins from each column or they can remove an entire column. The player’s objective is to force their opponent to take the last coin.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's instructions open in a new window

The start of a game.
There's not much else to show because at the end of the game there's just a blank window with all the coins removed

title: Jeu d'Henri

description:
Jpuzzle is a single-player, mouse controlled, jigsaw game. This game takes any file in .bmp format and breaks it into rectangular pieces, four pieces is the minimum and four hundred is the maximum, the player’s task is to re-assemble the original picture.

There are two game modes:* In jigsaw mode the player clicks on one piece and then on a second, the game then swaps the pieces around and gradually the original picture is reassembled.

  • In sliding mode the pieces are jumbled but one is removed and the player slides pieces into the vacant cell time and again until the original picture is restored

The game has a hint feature, a ‘show me which pieces are incorrect’ feature. The shareware version limits the number of pieces the jigsaw can be divided into. The registered version removes this restriction and has more pictures. For an additional cost the developer would provide a personalized jigsaw which included a picture supplied by the purchaser.

sample_screenshots.caption: It is possible to use a .bmp picture of your own
Pictures can be turned into sliding puzzles
The game opens with one of it's pictures ready to play
The moby logo scrambled in jigsaw form together with the drop down menu that selects the puzzle complexity

title: Jpuzzle

description:
Oilcap Pro is a single-player, shareware, mouse controlled puzzle Pipe Mania type of game.

The game area consists of an 8 x 11 grid. In one cell is the oil rig and in another there is usually a bonus section of pipe. When the game starts the player has a short time to select sections of pipe from the menu on the left and place them onto the grid. The objective being to create as long a run of pipe as possible for the oil to flow through.

Each level gives the player a target score to achieve in order to progress to the next. As the player progresses through the levels the oil flows faster and the initial pause before the oil flows becomes shorter. Higher levels have multiple oil rigs, bonus squares, sink holes - if oil flows into one of these it will emerge from another, and obstacles.

The shareware game has seven levels while the registered game has fifty, it was developed using Macromedia.

sample_screenshots.caption: A game in progress. The oil is flowing and, unless the next section of pipe is added quickly it will soon be over
Game Over. It's OK to have the oil run out of the pipe as long as the target score, upper left, has been reached
The game's title is displayed over the game grid
The game's instructions are displayed within the game and not in a separate window

title: Oilcap Pro

description:
PentaBlox is a single player, shareware implementation of the traditional puzzle Pentominoes.

Pentas are shapes made from five connected squares, this means that they all have the same area but a different shape. The player’s task is to fit the shapes into a box. There are twelve shapes in total which must be fitted into a box. The shareware game has just a 6x10 box but the registered game has three other box sizes 5 x 12, 4 x 15, and 3 x 20.

Pieces may be rotated and/or flipped in order to position them in the box and there’s an optional grid setting to help with the planning.

sample_screenshots.caption: By default the game opens in a window but it can also be played in full screen mode

Here the grid option has been enabled.
The drop down menu shows the other box sizes that are available in the registered version

title: PentaBlox

description:
Pudge is a single player, Soko-Ban style puzzle game. It was originally developed and released on the Atari ST.

The story behind the game is that the nasty Naggons have been using Pudge’s home planet, Stacia, as a dumping ground for all their radioactive waste. As Pudge the player is faces with thirty two screens filled with radioactive earth, radiation canisters, time bombs, Naggons and more which must be cleaned up. As each level is cleared the player is given a password so that they can start the game from the next level when they return to it.

The game plays in a window, it can be played with either the keyboard or a joystick, has no save game function.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game has thirty-two levels and a demo mode which lets you see every one of them
The game has a help file which can be accessed via the menu bar. It opens in a new window

Level 1
The game has not yet started so Pudge has full health and there's lots of time left before the bomb explodes

title: Pudge

description: Shuttle is a single player, freeware game in which the player navigates a space shuttle through gaps in a barrier, then lands the craft and finally parks it on a designated spot. As the player progresses through the eight levels the craft moves faster, the number of barriers increases and the time limits for the tasks decrease.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level one: part two. Landing the shuttle. As the game progresses the runway becomes shorter and the shuttle moves faster

Level one: part three. Parking the shuttle
As the player moves through the levels the background colour changes and the time available decreases
By level five the craft is moving faster and there are extra barriers

The start of a game
The shuttle does not start to rise until the player clicks on it. At that point the control buttons, currently greyed out, become active

title: Shuttle

description:
Squark is a single player, keyboard controlled, strategy game.

The game is played on a modified grid containing squares and rectangles. The player controls a red marble that always starts in the top left corner of the grid. The objective being to travel around all four sides of every square thus claiming them and clearing the level, the rectangles don’t get cleared and don’t score points they just make each level unique.

In the lower right corner of the grid is a green marble, this patrols the grid and any contact with it costs a life. Every thirty seconds the game adds a new green marble to the grid making a speedy clearance of the grid essential. Like Pac-man there are yellow dots randomly placed on the grid’s pathways, when the red marble passes over one of these the green marbles turn white and become vulnerable for a short while and they can be killed for bonus points.

The shareware version of the game has six levels, the registered version has thirty levels and a save game function.

sample_screenshots.caption: The start of level one. The player is in the top left, the first opponent is in the lower right. There's one yellow power dot and twenty squares to go around
Playing the game. One square has been cleared and six more have been partially cleared
The game area and title screen. This follows Soleau Software's logo
The game holds the top ten scores and the name of the players who achieved them

title: Squark

description:
Tai Chi Game is a shareware, single player, keyboard controlled, falling block puzzle.

The game takes its inspiration from the Tai Chi philosophy which is extensively described in the game’s documentation and all the blocks that fall are Tai Chi symbols. In terms of gameplay however the objective of the game is to score points by matching three identical symbols horizontally, vertically or diagonally – the matched symbols disappear and those above them drop down. To clear a level the player must remove all the ‘emptiness’ symbols from the screen, they are the grey squares in the screenshots, all levels are timed.

What makes this game different to most falling block puzzles is that falling icons can be changed as they descend so the player can cycle through the Tai Chi symbols thus making matching symbols easier. The player also has Tai Chi energy can be used to turn the falling block into a Tai Chi symbol, this crashes through the symbols on the bottom of the game area clearing a patch for future matches. The is can be done three times before the Tai Chi energy runs out however the player can generate more by aligning five category symbols in a horizontal line.

There are two modes of play, the standard mode as described above and an ‘advanced’ mode in which the falling icon interacts with the block it hits. The shareware game is limited to five levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: The shareware game starts with a title screen that is displayed over a blank game area
The game has a detailed help file which can be accessed via the menu bar
The action keys can be redefined
The game screen before a game begins

title: Tai Chi Game

description:
Moraff's Tinyjongg is a single player, mouse controlled game released to promote Moraff's Morejongg.

The game is fully playable but lacks some of the functionality of the full game, for example the option to load an external tileset brings up a message saying that this is available in the extended version of Moraff's Morejongg,

As with all games of this type the object is to remove all the tiles from the play area by matching pairs of exposed tiles. The game has the following game modes:* A Traditional

  • A Big Tile game
  • Mega Game
  • Preview: This game says that the full version of Moraff's Morejongg has twenty-four Big Tile layouts and twenty-four Mega game layouts, Moraff's Tinyjongg has just one example of each. Available via the menu bar is a preview mode in which the player gets to watch a game being played on any of these.

The game has sound effects, high score tables and statistics for each game type, together with hint, undo, and save/load functions. Game statistics are optional and for each layout there are one thousand possible deals of the tiles.

sample_screenshots.caption: External tilesets cannot be used in this game, this is not a problem though it's an opportunity to promote Moraff's Morejongg
This may be a reduced version of Moraff's Morejongg but there are still lots of options

The game starts with the traditional layout.
Note that the menu bar is used to prompt the player to start a game, in later screenshots the game's name is shown
It may not be possible to change the tileset but the base colour can be altered
The start of a game. The name is now in the menu bar and the score shows the number of tiles remaining

title: Moraff's Tinyjongg

description:
Touzai-Mahjong is an implementation of the traditional four player game, it is a Japanese shareware game that is mouse controlled. It caters for many rule variations including double tile under Kong tile; double tile under Double tile; allowing/preventing tiles being picked from the wall and more.

The player can choose their opponents but this is purely cosmetic as there is no documented difference in their gameplay. It is unusual in that during play uses multiple windows, one for the game area and one each for the four players.

sample_screenshots.caption: A game in progress. It is difficult to fit all the windows onto a small screen
The game caters for many rule variations
The shareware game starts with two nag screens. Each is displayed for twenty seconds
There is a good information file for this game. Isn't scoring complicated!

title: Touzai-Mahjong

description:
Vyper is a single player, keyboard controlled, Snake variant.

In this implementation of the game the player controls a snake who lives in Mayan ruins in Cancun. As all snakes do you like to eat flowers and must eat all the flowers on the screen to progress to the next level. Special ‘venom flowers’ allow you to eat the spiders that would otherwise kill you. Unlike many Snake games the player does not wander around a blank screen, each level has different obstacles and pitfalls. The shareware version of the game has five levels and the registered version has fifty.

Registration earns the player a code which removes the shareware reminder screens and increases the number of levels.

The game also comes with a level designer.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game comes with a level designer

Playing Level Two
The spiders only kill the snake if they make contact with the head
The unregistered game starts with a shareware nag screen

The start of Level One
The snake is in the egg over on the left

title: Vyper

description:
Robot Battle was a programming game in which players used RSL (Robot Scripting language) to create robots which they then used to battle other player’s creations on-line. A fee was charged for entry into these contests, early contests cost $10 to enter but this was reduced to $5 in 1995.

The game was developed and released by Brad Schick in 1994 and at that time the robots were 2D and were viewed top down. It went through many upgrades and versions before being sold to GarageGames in 2004. There is a story behind the game which sees robot fighting become legal in the year 4000. As a newly graduated programmer you have been asked to build a fighting robot to represent the Vega system in the Intergalactic Robot Battle Contest. Succeed and you may never have to work again, fail and “you'll probably end up writing new versions of Vega Calculator in some half-forgotten VegaSoft building on one of the twenty moons of Vega Panet.”

Robot Battle (version 1.2) of the software came with these pre-configured robots Corners, Events, Fire, Rammer, Shell, Side and Target. The scripting for each could be viewed and used as the basis for new designs which could then be tested in a local battle and/or be swapped with other members of the community. It came with three .exe files;* winrob.exe: This is the main game and is used to set up local battles between robots

  • distrib.exe: Is a program that scrambles a robots code, this is used when swapping robots with other members of the Robot Battle community. Robots scrambled by this process could not be entered into contests, 'plain' code had to be used for that..
  • contest.exe: Used to submit player details, robots, and make payments when entering competitions.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game comes with seven predefined robots. Any can be selected to battle against the others. On the Robot Selection screen, hidden here, is an option to specify the number of games
The instruction screen for submitting a robot to a contest
When the battle is over the statistics are displayed

title: Robot Battle

description:
Lode Runner is a one or two player, shareware game in which the player(s) explore underground caverns seeking gold, climbing ladders, avoiding traps and guards.

The game is, by default, keyboard controlled but the documentation does give instructions on how to configure a joystick.

This eight level game is probably a demo version of Lode Runner: The Legend Returns. Stylistically the two games are very similar though the background artwork differs slightly and the design of the levels is different. Two things connect this game closely with Lode Runner: The Legend Returns, one is that the player is chased by mad monks in red habits and the other is the drop down music menu which features the same worlds as Lode Runner: The Legend Returns.

sample_screenshots.caption: The title screen and main menu.
This screen is used to redefine the action keys
Level One: The menu bar is usually hidden during gameplay, it's shown when the mouse cursor moves close to the top of the screen
The game's level editor showing the drop down music menu which matches the worlds in Lode Runner: The Legend Returns

title: Lode Runner

description:
Maze O’ Doom is a single player, keyboard controlled, top-down mini-game. It is one of the games from Hodj 'n' Podj that was released separately to promote interest in the full product.

The player has find their way out of the haunted enchantemite mines, the ghosts who inhabit the place make many of the walls invisible and lay traps for those who enter their realm. The objective of the game is to find the exit within the time limit

This game has just three levels and allows the player to adjust the time limit and the number of invisible walls, the Maze O’ Doom game that is part of the full product randomly generates a new maze each time it is played and does not allow such customization.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's information file opens in-game
The title screen refers to the full product
A shameless plug for the full game
The start of a game. Compare this with the next screenshot to see how much of the game is hidden

title: Maze O' Doom

description:
Peggleboz is a single player, mouse controlled mini-game, it is a cut down version one of the games from Hodj 'n' Podj that was released separately to promote interest in the full product.

The game is an implementation of Peg Solitaire in which, according to the story created for Hodj 'n' Podj, the fishermen of Patshwerque play for shots of whiskey. This game has one level, the full mini-game has four, and is set in a tavern where shot glasses replace the traditional pegs. The object is to leave as few glasses as possible, leaving just one glass in the centre scores the maximum score of 25 points

sample_screenshots.caption: The game area and main menu
The game area at the start of a game. Clicking on the dartboard triggers a humerous animation, on the bottle undoes a move, and clicking on a glass picks it up prior to moving it
Game over! The score is based on the number of glasses left, leaving just one glass in the centre scores  the maximum score of 25 points
The title screen refers to the parent game
The shameless marketing plug for the full game

title: Peggleboz

description:
Super Qube Hopper is a single player, shareware, Q*bert style game in which the player has to bounce Qubey around the screen changing all the blocks to a target colour. Naturally there are baddies trying to stop Qubey in his quest and contact with these will cost a life, the player has two lives in the shareware version of the game but in the registered version they have four lives and gain another life for every five thousand points scored.

The game is mouse or joystick controlled, has sound and voice effects and a high score table. It occupies a fixed sized window on-screen within which the game plays. The game also comes with a level construction set.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game plays in this window which cannot be resized
The title screen and game menu. The highest score scrolls right to left across the bottom half of the screen
This is displayed before the start of a level

title: Super Qube Hopper

description:
WinRoids is a shareware Asteroids clone where you have to destroy every asteroid on the level while avoiding being hit by the debris (asteroids get split into smaller parts when hit) and the occasional flying saucers. The game uses newtonian physics which means that you use your thrusters to accelerate in a direction, and the ship keeps moving in that direction and velocity - regardless of the current direction your ship is pointing - until you use your thrusters again to decelerate or change your direction.

The levels are on a single screen with looped borders. Anything that exits the screen on one side, will enter the screen on the other. This includes your own shots. Apart from the random enemy UFOs, there are also randomly appearing bonus crates containing extra lives, weapon upgrades and shield generators. The graphics are high resolution (for 1994) pre-rendered 2D sprites in cartoon or 50's sci-fi style.

sample_screenshots.caption: The shield is being used to counter an asteroid impact
The metal sphere with spikes is indestructible.

title: WinRoids

description:
Canfield is a single person, shareware, mouse controlled implementation of Canfield Solitaire. This implementation has five difficulty settings, undo, cheat function and autoplay functions, and the game keeps statistics.

The game is played with a standard deck of fifty-two cards. In this game the player starts by turning over a card, it can be any card but for the sake of explaining the game assume it is the five of clubs. That card forms one of the foundations and the player must build four foundations, one for each suit, starting with the five in an ascending sequence through queen, king, ace and then ‘wrapping around to the two, three and four. While they are doing this they will encounter other cards that they can play onto four holding stacks, cards are placed here in descending sequence red on black/black on red.

sample_screenshots.caption: There is a detailed information file with this game
There are lots of configuration options tucked away in the menu bar
The game starts with a shareware reminder screen

title: Canfield

description:
Magic Words is a single player, shareware, Tetris style game.

This, however, is Tetris with a twist, instead of matching coloured blocks to form lines and score points, here the player is given blocks containing letters and has to form words. Each level has a target, for example level one’s target is to form the word ‘HELLO’ which sounds simple enough but within the word ‘Hello’ are the words ‘Ell’ and ‘Hell’ so if they are completed before the full word the letters disappear and all the preceding good work has been undone. Once the target has been achieved the game continues with blocks falling ever faster until the screen is filled, that completes the level but does not end the game, the player then enters their name for the high score table and moves on to the next level.

All the falling blocks consist of two letters, words can be made horizontally or vertically and the game can be played either with the keyboard or the joystick. The shareware game has fifteen levels while the registered game has one hundred and twenty. The game also plays in English or German.

sample_screenshots.caption: The high score table comes pre-populated with three scores by 'Magic'
The start of a game. The target for Level One is over on the left, it's to form the word HELLO but ELL is also a word
The target for Level two was to make two words. Once that was achieved the blocks kept falling faster and faster until the screen was filled to the top.
Oh Bother! The target for Level One is the word HELLO but HELL is also a word
The title screen is displayed after the shareware reminder

title: Magic Words

description: Jixxa is a jigsaw puzzle game. The shareware version comes with two jigsaws to solve. The player can drag a puzzle piece and connect the pieces together just like a real jigsaw, and also includes a number of features such as nailing pieces, in-game timer, and the ability to play MIDI music from your computer. The game features an online help system and documentation.
title: Jixxa

description:
100 Great Kid's Games: Vol II is a compilation of assorted shareware and freeware games for children.

The game's setup.exe file has to be run manually from the disc, this installs Softkey's CD-Guide onto the user's hard drive, this is a disc browser program that allows the user to access and install the programs. The games here are a mix of educational and arcade style games. The games are listed in alphabetical order together with a brief description, a game browser button will open any additional documentation in a separate window. Among the included games are Ack-Ack Attack! a DOS game, Beetle Run from Soleau Software, Blobshop, Comet Busters! , Dino Cards, Dino Match, Dino Numbers, Dino Slots, Dino Spell, Dino Tiles, Dirt Bike from Brad Quick, Earth Words For Alien Dinosaurs, Gravity Well, MVP Word Search for Windows V2.1, Sea School, The Egg Carton Game and Zee Artillery.

Not all programs are compatible with all versions of Windows.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Softkey CD browser is installed onto the hard drive and the player uses it to access the games
Some of the games play direct from the CD but occasionally this does not work because they have specific requirements
This UK release was probably released much earlier in the USA
Where there is documentation the CD browser opens it in a new window

title: 100 Great Kid's Games: Vol II

description:
Golf Patience is a shareware solitaire card game from AG Crump Software. It was released independently as a ‘taster’ game for their Solitaire Gold Pack, anyone registering Golf Patience received the full solitaire suite in return.

Golf Patience aka Golf Solitaire is a classic solitaire game which the player has around a 26% chance of winning. The game is uses card number/rank only – suits are unimportant. It starts with thirty cards dealt face up, six rows of five cards. The player then turns the cards from the pile of remaining cards over one at a time. These cards are used to match to the face-up cards and hopefully clear runs of cards in one go.
Card matching is best explained by example; so if a ten is turned over from the card stack it would match to either a nine or a jack on the rows of turned cards. If the player matches to a jack then they can either match that to another ten or to a queen among the face up cards. This process is repeated until there are no more cards that match.

The game has sound and a choice of card back

sample_screenshots.caption: The program starts with a pre-dealt game ready to play. Here the card turned over on the stack is the ten, it allows the player to remove either a jack or a nine
There is a choice of card backs
Registering this game gets the full suite
There is in-game help, it opens in a small, separate window

Game Over.
No more cards can be played

title: Golf Patience

description:
Monte Carlo Patience is a shareware solitaire card game from AG Crump Software. It was released independently as a ‘taster’ game for their Solitaire Gold Pack, anyone registering Golf Patience received the full solitaire suite in return.

Monte Carlo Patience aka Monte Carlo Solitaire, aka Weddings aka ‘Double and Quits’ is a classic solitaire game which the player has around a 5% chance of winning, it’s popular because it is quick and easy to play.

The game is uses card number/rank only – suits are unimportant. It starts with twenty-five cards being dealt in five rows of five cards, pairs of cards of the same rank are removed if they are horizontally, vertically or diagonally next to each other. When there are no more cards to remove the player clicks on the ‘DEAL’ button which shuffles the remaining cards together and adds new cards to the 5x5 grid. The process is repeated until either all cards are removed or no more pairs can be found.

The game has sound but does not have a choice of card backs

sample_screenshots.caption: Game Over - none of the remaining pairs are adjacent
A game in progress. Here pairs have been removed, there's just one remaining - two sixes - before the cards are consolidated and the empty slots are filled
The game was released as a 'taster' game for the Solitaire Gold pack
There is no title or splash screen, this game loads with a new game immediately ready to play
There is in-game help. It opens in a small separate window

title: Monte Carlo Patience

description:
Treasure Trove Solitaire is a shareware solitaire card game from AG Crump Software that also goes by the name of Osmosis Solitaire. It was released independently as a ‘taster’ game for their Solitaire Gold Pack, anyone registering Treasure Trove Solitaire received the full solitaire suite in return.

The object of the game is to end up with four piles of thirteen cards all of the same suit, order is unimportant.
Sixteen cards are dealt face down into four piles of four cards, the top card of each pile is turned face up. A seventeenth card is played into the game area, this is the foundation of the first suit. All other cards that are face up are moved to that pile in such a way that their rank remains visible. The value of the first card is doubly important because the piles for the other suits MUST begin with a card of that rank, so if the first pile started with the ten of clubs the piles for spades, hearts and diamonds cannot begin until the ten of that suit becomes available.

The other rule for this game is that cards can only be played to their relevant pile if the pile on the left contains a number of the same rank. To continue our example the first pile starts with the ten of clubs and the five and six are face up so they get moved to the same pile. Luckily the ten of hearts is also free so a pile of hearts can be started then we begin working through the pack. The seven of hearts is turned over. Even though the heart suit is being built the seven cannot be added to it because there’s no seven among the clubs that have currently been played.

The game has sound and a choice of card backs

sample_screenshots.caption: When registering this game the player receives the full Solitare Gold Pack
There's no title screen, the program loads with a game ready to play. here the Queen is the foundation of the first suit, clubs. All the other club scan be added to that pile
In this game the first foundation card was a five. The five of spades has found now we have a spade pile. The four of spades cannot be played because there's no four in the club pile
A game in progress. None of these queens can be played because there's no queen in the clubs pile.

title: Treasure Trove Solitaire

description:
Napoleon Solitaire is a shareware solitaire suite containing twenty-one variations on Forty Thieves solitaire also known as Napoleon at St Helena, Roosevelt, San Juan.

The basic game is played with two decks of cards. It has eight foundations where cards are built upwards by suit from ace to king and ten stacks of four cards ( this is where the forty thieves name originates.

The variations here are; Forty Thieves, Little Napoleon, Diplomat, Josephine, Rank and File, Number Ten, Congress, Indian, Maria, Midshipman, Limited, Blind Alleys, Single Rail, Little Forty, Waterloo, Corona, Australian Patience, Double Rail, Giant, Napoleon’s Square & Blockade. Forty Thieves requires a screen resolution of 800x600, the remainder play in a resolution of 600x480.

The suite has a choice of card back, choice of background, game statistics, undo/redo and save game options. The package also includes the Napoleon Solitaire Game Wizard whereby custom games can be created, user created games do not appear in the game's menu, they are created and accessed via the game wizard.

The shareware version was available for a thirty day trial period after which the player was required to register, when registering the player could request a version of the game without the shareware nag screen, these were shipped on floppy disc for a nominal fee.

sample_screenshots.caption: There's a summary of the game for the supplied games and the user created games
Here we have Moby Solitaire - created via the Napoleon Solitaire Game Wizard
The in-game help option is accessed via the menu bar.

title: Napoleon Solitaire

description:
Cardfun: Canfield is a solitaire game from Wyvern Studios and is part of their Cardfun range.

Canfield is a solitaire game which originated in New York and was played in casinos in the 1890’s. When played with casino rules, i.e. no undo / redo and going through the deck three cards at a time, it is quite hard to win but with the use of an undo function some sources claim a success rate of over 30% and with unlimited passes through the deck and turning over one card at a time success rates approaching 90% have been claimed.

This game was sold separately and it was also part of Wyvern’s Solitaire Fun package. It has an autoplay function, options to play the owner's CD or MIDI music, change the card back, use larger card numbers & two kinds of scoring,it has an undo function and games can be saved.

The game starts with the game dealing five cards, four cards are available for the player to use and the fifth becomes the first foundation card. The foundation card is important because it's value determined the value of the foundations for the remaining three suits, so if the card turned up was the ten of clubs the player could not start building piles of hearts, diamonds and spades until they had the ten of those suits. Once a foundation card has been played cards are added to it in sequence so in our example the jack would go on the ten, queen on the jack, king on the queen, ace on the king, two on the ace and so-on finishing with the nine.
If any of the four face-up cards can be added to a foundation the player does so filling in the space with a card from the top of the deck. The player then goes through the deck playing cards to the foundations wherever possible.
This game allows the player to work through the deck either looking at every third card or every card.

The shareware version of the game only allows a limited number of games before the player is required to register.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game could be registered on-line
There is no title screen, the game loads like this and is immediately ready to play. Here the jack is the foundation card and three have been auto-played already together with a queen
The game plays in a window and has an option to play in a half-size window
The game is hard to solve so we were surprised to win it at the first attempt. The game was surprised too because it locked up

title: Cardfun: Canfield

description: Midnight Puzzle is a typical puzzle game. The game includes 10 different puzzles, with 2 difficulty levels (10x10 and 20x20). New pictured may be purchased after completing all the pictures available. The game uses adjustable window with drop down menu system.
title: Midnight Puzzle

alternate_titles.title: Payuta et le Dieu des tempêtes
Payuta y el Dios de la Tempestad

description: Payuta and the Ice God is an interactive game for children. Kiagnyk the ice god terrorizes the arctic people and kidnaps Opiak. Her brother Payuta challenges the ice god to free his sister. Included are puzzles, memory and skill games in which you learn about life and lore of the Inuit.
title: Payuta and the Ice God

alternate_titles.title: Video Cube: The Video Puzzle Game

description:
Video Cube: Space is the first in a planned series of puzzle games from Aris Entertainment.

This is a form of jigsaw. The player is presented with a square representing one side of a cube. This square is broken into elements (smaller squares) each of which is one face of a smaller cube. The object is to rotate all the elements until they form a picture, at which point the still picture becomes a short animated/video clip, and to repeat the process for all six sides of the video cube. Completing all six sides completes a level in the game, there are eighteen levels and they are timed – run out of time and it’s game over.

The game has sound effects, music, a high score table and a boss key, it must be run with 256 colours.

sample_screenshots.caption: The game's help file is opened by clicking on an icon on the right of the game screen. It opens in a separate resizeable window

The Video Cube has arrived
The pictures to be completed are show in tiny squares in the top right
The squares in the upper right show three pictures have been completed. In the centre a fourth is about complete. However the clock at the bottom shows only twelve seconds left
The game comes with a pre-populated high score table
The title screen. The game pauses here waiting for a user id. After this comes an animated introduction

title: Video Cube: Space

description: De Grote bosatlas: 51e Editie is the 51st edition of a Dutch atlas that was first published in 1877. This edition is the first to include a diskette with an electronic version. Included on the diskette is a game that teaches topography. Player's can choose between various maps (Netherlands, Europe, Asia, World, Etc.) and must use the mouse which is shaped as a UFO to select the location of given cities or other geographical features. The player is scored and the best scores are kept in a high score table.
title: De Grote Bosatlas: 51e Editie

description: A little known submarine simulation game, where you have to patrol the Atlantic as a captain of a German U-boat during the World War II.

sample_screenshots.caption: The main menu of the game
The map of the North Atlantic

title: Grey Wolf: Hunter of the North Atlantic

description: The Prince and the Prankster: The Quest for the Magical Seeds is an advergame for the apple-based products of the American company Mott's. In this game the player must assist the prince in Appleshire where a prankster has stolen all the fruit. This is done by gathering clues and solving word puzzles. By finding seeds, the fruit magically starts to grow again.
title: Mott's Presents The Prince and the Prankster: The Quest for the Magical Seeds

description: Grid based Windows 3.x RPG in which the hero attempts to escape from a dungeon. The protagonist is a elven warrior who was thrown into the dungeon while trying to stop the evil wizard Rand. You explore the grid fighting increasingly difficult enemies, while collecting better weapons and armor. The player also finds colored gems, which they use to cast spells.
title: Haven

description:
OrtoGra is an educational game. The player's task is to learn the correct spelling. The gameplay is divided into two stages. In the first one the player moves in a specific location, looking for items whose spelling is difficult. After finding an item the player must select the proper letter before the time runs out. The second stage is just a classic dictation.

Belfer is not a game. It's an educational program.
title: OrtoGra / Belfer

description:
In the year 2105, all highways are mechanized and automated, rearranged by a central computer in real time to reduce traffic congestion. The player takes on the role of an unscrupulous taxi driver, who has outfitted his taxi with a hacking device, allowing him to take control of the highways and ensure his trips are as long and expensive as possible.

Street Shuffle is a puzzle game where you slide tiles connecting roads, to ensure your taxi gets from one corner of the screen to the other. After a initial delay to allow the player to setup some tiles, the taxi starts moving, therefore the player must think quickly to move the tiles and complete the puzzle before it is too late. The game is similar to the "connect pipes" puzzle genre, where instead of a car, it is a liquid that flows. Driving into a dead-end, returning to the starting point, running out of fuel, or repeatedly driving along the same path, all cause the player to fail the level.

The game also includes a strategy element. After completing every level, the player receives money which can be spent on refueling the taxi, repairing damage incurred by crashing, or buying special equipment (which is necessary to avoid damage or crashing on certain roads). The longer the path taken by the player's taxi, the more money is received for that level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level failed - your cab has crashed
Level 3 - Bonus. Here the rules are different: you assemble the road from given tiles, "Pipe Dream"-style
Game over - ran out of gas

title: Street Shuffle

description: Freddie Trims A Tree is a Christmas themed point and click adventure game. It is made with the Klik & Play game engine. The player controls a fox named Freddie. The goal is to find and decorate a Christmas tree for Mrs. Wolfington.
title: Freddie Trims A Tree

description:
MemGame is a freeware, two player, mouse controlled, concentration game. It can be played player vs player or player vs computer.
